945983_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. (the Company, us, we, or our ) is an information technology ( IT ) channel company.
945983_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	We resell software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States and Canada.
945983_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	We also distribute software through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_11_ITEM1_P0_S3	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization, networking, software development, database modeling, security, and other technically sophisticated domains.
945983_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.
945983_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our Common Stock is listed on the Nasdaq Global Market under the symbol WSTG .
945983_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our main web site address is www.waysidetechnology.com, and the other web sites maintained by our business include www.lifeboatdistribution.com, www.programmers.com, and www.techxtend.com.
945983_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	Reference to these uniform resource locators or URLs is made as an inactive textual reference for informational purposes only.
945983_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	Information on our web sites should not be considered filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and is not, and should not be deemed to be, a part of this report.
945983_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Lifeboat segment distributes technical software through a worldwide network of corporate and value-added resellers, consultants, and systems integrators.
945983_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Programmer s segment sells technical software, hardware, and services for microcomputers, servers, and networks to individual programmers, corporations, government agencies, and educational institutions primarily in the United States and Canada.
945983_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	For each of our segments, revenues from unaffiliated customers, income and total assets, among other financial information, is presented in Note 10 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
945983_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	The software market is highly competitive.
945983_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	Pricing is very aggressive in both software distribution and reselling.
945983_11_ITEM1_P5_S2	The Company expects pricing pressure to continue.
945983_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company faces competition from a wide variety of sources.
945983_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	In the Lifeboat segment, we compete against much larger broad-line distributors, as well as specialty distributors and, in some cases, the direct sales teams of the vendors we represent also sell directly to the end-customers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	In the Programmers segment, we also compete against vendors who sell directly to customers, as well as software resellers, superstores, e-commerce vendors, and other direct marketers of software products.
945983_11_ITEM1_P6_S3	In both segments, some of our competitors are significantly larger and have substantially greater resources than the Company.
945983_11_ITEM1_P6_S4	Many of our competitors compete principally on the basis of price, product availability, customer service and technical su pport.
945983_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	There can be no assurance that the Company can compete effectively against existing competitors or new competitors that may enter the market or that it can generate profit margins which represent a fair return to the Company.
945983_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	In addition, price is an important competitive factor in the personal computer software market and there can be no assurance that the Company will not be subject to increased price competition.
945983_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	An increase in the amount of competition faced by the Company, or its failure to compete effectively against its competitors, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations.
945983_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company competes to attract prospective buyers and in sourcing new products from software developers and publishers, as well as in marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	The Company believes that its ability to offer software developers and IT professionals a wide selection of products at reasonable prices with prompt delivery and high customer service levels, along with its good relationships with vendors and suppliers, allows it to compete effectively in acquiring prospective buyers and marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	The Company competes to gain distribution rights for new products primarily on the basis of its reputation and its relationships with software publishers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	The market for developer and infrastructure software products is characterized by rapid changes in technology, user requirements, and customer specifications.
945983_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	The manner in which software products are distributed and sold is changing, and new methods of distribution and sale may emerge or expand.
945983_11_ITEM1_P10_S2	Software developers and publishers have sold, and may intensify their efforts to sell, their products directly to end-users.
945983_11_ITEM1_P10_S3	The continuing evolution of the Internet as a platform in which to conduct e-commerce business transactions has both lowered the barriers for competition and broadened customer access to products and information, increasing competition and reducing prices.
945983_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	From time to time, certain software developers and publishers have instituted programs for the direct sale of large order quantities of software to certain major corporate accounts.
945983_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	These types of programs may continue to be developed and used by various developers and publishers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	While Microsoft and other vendors currently sell new releases or upgrades directly to end users, they have not, however, attempted to completely bypass the reseller channel.
945983_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	There can be no assurances that software developers and publishers will continue using resellers to the same extent they currently do.
945983_11_ITEM1_P12_S2	Future efforts by software developers and publishers to bypass third- party sales channels could materially and adversely affect the Company s business operations and financial conditions.
945983_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	In addition, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services.
945983_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	Any of these competitive programs, if successful, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, result of operations and financial condition.
945983_11_ITEM1_P13_S2	For a description of additional risks relating to competition in our industry, please refer to Item 1.A. Risk Factors We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell and The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business.
945983_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	The Company offers a wide variety of products from a broad range of publishers and manufacturers, including CA Technologies Inc., Quest Software, Inc., GFI Software, Intel Corporation, Infragistics, TechSmith Corporation, Flexera Corp., Acronis, Solarwinds, and Veeam Corporation.
945983_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	On a continuous basis, we screen new products for inclusion in our catalogs and web sites based on their features, quality, price, profit margins and warranties, as well as on current sales trends.
945983_11_ITEM1_P14_S2	Since the Company predominantly sells software, sales of hardware and peripherals represented only 4%, 7% and 4%, of our overall revenue in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
945983_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	We market products through creative marketing communications, including our web sites, local and on-line seminars, print and electronic catalogs.
945983_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	We also use direct e-mail and printed material to introduce new products and upgrades, to cross-sell products to current customers, and to educate and inform existing and potential customers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	We believe that our blend of electronic and traditional marketing and selling programs are important marketing vehicles for software publishers and manufacturers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P15_S3	These programs provide a cost-effective and service-oriented means to market and sell and fulfill software products and meet the needs of users.
945983_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	The Company had one customer that accounted for more than 10% of total sales for 2010.
945983_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2010, CDW Corporation accounted for 15.8% of consolidated net sales and, as of December 31, 2010, 12.8% of total net accounts receivable.
945983_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2009, CDW Corporation and Software House International accounted for 10.5% and 10.7%, respectively, of consolidated net sales.
945983_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	The Company had no major customers that accounted for more than 10% of total sales for 2008.
945983_11_ITEM1_P16_S4	Our top five customers accounted for 44%, 36%, and 31% of consolidated net sales in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
945983_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	The Company generally ships products within 48 hours of confirming a customer s order.
945983_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	This allows for minimum backlog in the business.
945983_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	Sales in Canada represented 7% of our consolidated revenues in 2010, as compared to 8% in 2009, and 11% in 2008.
945983_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	Sales in Canada increased in absolute dollars in 2010 as compared to 2009, but decreased as a percentage of consolidated revenues due to overall increased sales volume in other regions.
945983_11_ITEM1_P18_S2	For geographic financial information, please refer to Note 10 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
945983_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	We believe that providing a high level of customer service is necessary to compete effectively and is essential to continued sales and revenue growth.
945983_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Our account representatives assist our customers with all aspects of purchasing decisions, process products ordered and respond to customer inquiries on order status, product pricing and availability.
945983_11_ITEM1_P19_S2	The account representatives are trained to answer all basic questions about the features and functionality of products.
945983_11_ITEM1_P19_S3	To deal with technical issues, we maintain an in-house technical support staff.
945983_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	The Company s success is dependent, in part, upon the ability of its suppliers to develop and market products that meet the changing requirements of the marketplace.
945983_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	The Company believes it enjoys good relationships with its vendors.
945983_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	The Company and its principal vendors have cooperated frequently in product introductions and in other marketing programs.
945983_11_ITEM1_P20_S3	As is customary in the industry, the Company has no long-term supply contracts with any of its suppliers.
945983_11_ITEM1_P20_S4	Substantially all of the Company s contracts with its vendors are terminable upon 30 days notice or less.
945983_11_ITEM1_P20_S5	Moreover, the manner in which software products are distributed and sold is changing, and new methods of distribution and sale may emerge or expand.
945983_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	Software publishers have sold, and may intensify their efforts to sell, their products directly to end-users.
945983_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	The Company s business and results of operations may be ad versely affected if the terms and conditions of the Company s authorizations with its vendors were to be significantly modified or if certain products become unavailable to the Company.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	We believe that effective purchasing from a diverse vendor base is a key element of our business strategy.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2010, Quest was the only individual vendor from whom our purchases exceeded 10%.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2010 Quest accounted for 11.2% of our total purchases.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2009, Quest was similarly the only individual vendor from whom our purchases exceeded 10%, representing 10.2% of our total purchases.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2008, VMware and Quest accounted for 23.3% and 13%, respectively, of our total purchases.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S5	VMware terminated its distributor agreement with Lifeboat Distribution, Inc. in 2008.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S6	As a result, our Lifeboat segment ceased distributing VMware products as of October 1, 2008, the distribution of which had accounted for $29.2 million, or 17% of our 2008 revenue.
945983_11_ITEM1_P22_S7	Although we succ essfully replaced VMware, the loss of a key vendor or group of vendors could disrupt our product availability and otherwise have an adverse effect on the Company.
945983_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	In 2010, the Company purchased approximately 90% of its products directly from manufacturers and publishers and the balance from multiple distributors, as compared to 85% in 2009, and 90% in 2008.
945983_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Most suppliers or distributors will drop ship products directly to the customers, which reduces physical handling by the Company.
945983_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	Inventory management techniques, such as drop shipping allow the Company to offer a greater range of products without increased inventory requirements or associated risk.
945983_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Inventory levels may vary from period to period, due in part to increases or decreases in sales levels, the Company s practice of making large-volume purchases when it deems the terms of such purchases to be attractive, and the addition of new suppliers and products.
945983_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	Moreover, the Company s order fulfillment and inventory control systems allow the Company to order certain products just in time for next day shipping.
945983_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	The Company promotes the use of electronic data interchange ( EDI ) with its suppliers, which helps reduce overhead and the use of paper in the ordering process.
945983_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Although brand names and individual products are important to our business, we believe that competitive sources of supply are available for substantially all of the product categories we carry.
945983_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	The Company operates distribution facilities in Shrewsbury, New Jersey and Mississauga, Canada.
945983_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	The Company operates management information systems on Windows 2003 and Windows 2008 platforms that allow for centralized management of key functions, including inventory, accounts receivable, purchasing, sales and distribution.
945983_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	We are dependent on the accuracy and proper utilization of our information technology systems, including our telephone, web sites, e-mail and fax systems.
945983_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	The management information systems allow the Company to monitor sales trends, provide real time product availability and order status information, track direct marketing campaign performance and to make marketing event driven purchasing decisions.
945983_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	In addition to the main system, the Company has systems of networked personal computers, as well as microcomputer-based desktop publishing systems, which facilitate data sharing and provide an automated office environment.
945983_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	The Company recognizes the need to continually upgrade its management information systems to most effectively manage its operations and customer database.
945983_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	In that regard, the Company anticipates that it will, from time to time, require software and hardware upgrades for its present management information systems.
945983_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	The Company conducts its business under the various trademarks and service marks of Programmer s Paradise, the Island Man cartoon character logo, and Lifeboat.
945983_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	The Company protects these trademarks and service marks and believes that they have significant value to us and are important factors in our marketing programs.

945983_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should carefully consider the risk factors set forth below as well as the other information contained in this report.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or those currently viewed by us to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Changes in the information technology industry and/or economic environment may reduce demand for the products and services we sell.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our results of operations are influenced by a variety of factors, including the condition of the IT industry, general economic conditions, shifts in demand for, or availability of, computer products and software and IT services and industry introductions of new products, upgrades or methods of distribution.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The information technology products industry is characterized by abrupt changes in technology, rapid changes in customer preferences, short product life cycles and evolving industry standards.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Net sales can be dependent on demand for specific product categories, and any change in demand for or supply of such products could have a material adverse effect on our net sa les, and/or cause us to record write-downs of obsolete inventory, if we fail to react in a timely manner to such changes.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We acquire products for resale both directly from manufacturers and indirectly from distributors.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The loss of a supplier could cause a disruption in the availability of products.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Additionally, there is no assurance that as manufacturers continue to or increasingly sell directly to end users and through the distribution channel, that they will not limit or curtail the availability of their products to resellers like us.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S4	For example, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services, and correspon dingly, decrease the volume of products sold through us.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Our inability to obtain a sufficient quantity of products, or an allocation of products from a manufacturer in a way that favors one of our competitors, or competing distribution channels, relative to us, could cause us to be unable to fill clients orders in a timely manner, or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S6	We also rely on our suppliers to provide funds for us to market their products, including through our catalogs and on-line marketing efforts, and to provide purchasing incentives to us.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P3_S7	If any of the suppliers that have historically provided these benefits to us decides to reduce such benefits, our expenses would increase, adversely affecting our results of operations.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Lingering Effects of the Recent Economic Downturn May Reduce our Revenues and Profits.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The lingering ongoing effects of the general economic downturn continues to cause some of our current and potential customers to delay or reduce technology purchases, resulting in longer sales cycles, slower adoption of new technologies and increased price competition.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We may, therefore, experience a greater decline in demand for the products we sell, resulting in increased competition and pressure to reduce the cost of operations.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Any benefits from cost reductions may take longer to realize and may not fully mitigate the impact of the reduced demand.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P4_S4	In addition, weak financial and credit markets heighten the risk of customer bankruptcies and create a corresponding delay in collecting receivables f rom those customers and may also affect our vendors ability to supply products, which could disrupt our operations.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P4_S5	The realization of any or all of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Competition has been based primarily on price, product availability, speed of delivery, credit availability and quality and breadth of product lines and, increasingly, also is based on the ability to tailor specific solutions to client needs.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	We compete with manufacturers, including manufacturers of products we sell, as well as a large number and wide variety of marketers and resellers of IT products and services.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition, manufacturers are increasing the volume of software products they distribute electronically directly to end-users and in the future will likely pay lower referral fees for sales of certain software lic ensing agreements sold by us.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Generally, pricing is very aggressive in the industry, and we expect pricing pressures to continue.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	There can be no assurance that we will be able to negotiate prices as favorable as those negotiated by our competitors or that we will be able to offset the effects of price reductions with an increase in the number of clients, higher net sales, cost reductions, or greater sales of services, which service sales typically are at higher gross margins, or otherwise.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Price reductions by our competitors that we either cannot or choose not to match could result in an erosion of our market share and/or reduced sales or, to the extent we match such reductions, could result in reduced operating margins, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Disruptions in our information technology and voice and data networks could affect our ability to service our clients and cause us to incur additional expenses.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	We believe that our success to date has been, and future results of operations likely will be, dependent in large part upon our ability to provide prompt and efficient service to clients.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Our ability to provide such services is dependent largely on the accuracy, quality and utilization of the information generated by our IT systems, which affect our ability to manage our sales, client service, distribution, inventories and accounting systems and the reliability of our voice and data networks.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We depend on certain key personnel.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Our future success will be largely dependent on the efforts of key management personnel.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	We also believe that our future success will be largely dependent on our continued ability to attract and retain highly qualified management, sales, service and technical personnel.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P8_S3	We cannot assure you that we will be able to attract and retain such personnel.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Further, we make a significant investment in the training of our sales account executives.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P8_S5	Our inability to retain such personnel or to train them either rapidly enough to meet our expanding needs or in an effective manner for quickly changing market conditions could cause a decrease in the overall quality and efficiency of our sales staff, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operation s and financial condition.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Risks Related to Our Common Stock .
945983_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The exercise of outstanding options or any other issuance of shares by us may dilute your ownership of our Common Stock.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Our Common Stock is thinly traded.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P9_S3	As a result of the thin trading market for our stock, its market price may fluctuate significantly more than the stock market as a whole or of the stock prices of similar companies.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Without a larger float, our common stock will be less liquid than the stock of companies with broader public ownership, and, as a result, the trading prices for our Common Stock may be more volatile.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P9_S5	Among other things, trading of a relatively small volume of our Common Stock may have a greater impact on the trading price of our stock than would be the case if our public float were larger.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our common stock is listed on the Nasdaq Global Market, and we therefore are subject to continued listing requirements, include requirements with respect to the market value and number of publicly-held shares, number of stockholders, minimum bid price, number of market makers and either (i) stockholders equity or (ii) total market value of stock, total assets and total revenues.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If we fail to satisfy one or more of the requirements, we may be delisted from the Nasdaq Global Market.
945983_11_ITEM1A_P10_S2	If we are delisted from the Nasdaq Global Market, we do not qualify for listing on the Nasdaq Capital Market, and if we are not able to list our common stock on another exchange, our common stock could be quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board or on the pink sheets .
945983_11_ITEM1A_P10_S3	As a result, we could face significant adverse consequences including, among others, a limited availability of market quotations fo r our securities and a decreased ability to issue additional securities or obtain additional financing in the future.

945983_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
945983_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
945983_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company believes the following critical accounting policies used in the preparation of its consolidated financial statements affect its more significant judgments and estimates.
945983_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of its customers to make required payments.
945983_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	If the financial condition of the Company s customers were to deteriorate, resulting in an impairment of their ability to make payments, additional allowances may be required.
945983_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company writes down its inventory for estimated obsolescence or unmarketable inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
945983_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	If actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, additional inventory write-offs may be required.
945983_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company has considered future taxable income and ongoing prudent and feasible tax planning strategies in assessing the need for the valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets.
945983_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	In the event the Company were to determine that it would not be able to realize all or part of its net deferred tax assets in the future, an adjustment to the deferred tax assets would be charged to income in the period such determination was made.
945983_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	Under the fair value recognition provision, stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is the vesting period.
945983_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	We make certain assumptions in order to value and expense our various share-based payment awards.
945983_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	In connection with valuing stock options, we use the Black-Scholes model, which requires us to estimate certain subjective assumptions.
945983_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	The key assumptions we make are: the expected volatility of our stock; the expected term of the award; and the expected forfeiture rate.
945983_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	In connection with our restricted stock programs we make assumptions principally related to the forfeiture rate.
945983_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	We review our valuation assumptions periodically and, as a result, we may change our valuation assumptions used to value stock based awards granted in future period s.
945983_11_ITEM7_P67_S2	Such changes may lead to a significant change in the expense we recognize in connection with share-based payments.

945983_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	As required by Rule 13a-15(b) under the Exchange Act, our management carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures , as such term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act, as of the end of the period covered by this report.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P0_S2	This evaluation was carried out under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our Company s President, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer (principal executive officer) and Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer (principal financial officer).
945983_11_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Based upon that evaluation, the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer conclud ed that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective, as of the end of the period covered by this report, to ensure that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms and is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management, including the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) of the Exchange Act.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, and effected by the Board of Directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Internal control over financial reporting includes maintaining records in reasonable detail that accurately and fairly reflect our transactions and disposition of assets; providing reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of our financial statements in accordance with GAAP; providing reasonable assurance that receipts and expenditures of the Company, are made in accordance of with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and providing reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Company assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting is not intended to provide absolute assurance that a misstatement of our financial statements would be prevented or detected.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P1_S4	In addition, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that, owing to changes in conditions, controls may become inadequate, or that the degree of compliance with policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Based on this evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2010.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P2_S2	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2010 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
945983_11_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s registered public accounting firm.

945983_11_ITEM15_P38_S2	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding, adjusted for potentially dilutive securities.

945983_11_ITEM15_P41_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers but generally does not require collateral to support any outstanding obligation.
945983_11_ITEM15_P41_S2	Allowances for potential uncollectible amounts are estimated and deducted from total accounts receivable.
945983_11_ITEM15_P42_S0	We provide allowances for doubtful accounts related to accounts receivable for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.
945983_11_ITEM15_P42_S1	We take into consideration the overall quality and aging of the receivable portfolio along with specifically identified customer risks.
945983_11_ITEM15_P42_S2	If actual customer payment performance were to deteriorate to an extent not expected, additional allowances may be required.

945983_11_ITEM15_P43_S1	Cumulative translation adjustments have been classified within accumulated other comprehensive income, which is a separate component of stockholders equity in accordance ASC Topic No. 220, Comprehensive Income .

945983_11_ITEM15_P52_S1	The foreign currency translation adjustments are not currently adjusted for income taxes as they relate to permanent investments in international subsidiaries.

945983_11_ITEM15_P53_S1	Usual sales terms are FOB shipping point, at which time title and risk of loss has passed to the customer.
945983_11_ITEM15_P54_S0	Revenue is recognized in accordance with ASC Topic 985-605 Software Revenue Recognition and ASC Topic 605-10-S99, and ASC Topic 605-45, Reporting Revenue Gross as a Principal versus Net as an Agent .
945983_11_ITEM15_P54_S1	The majority of the Company s revenues relates to physical products and is recognized on a gross basis with the selling price to the customer recorded as net sales with the acquisition cost of the product to the Company recorded as cost of sales.
945983_11_ITEM15_P54_S2	At the time of sale, the Company also records an estimate for sales returns based on historical experience.
945983_11_ITEM15_P54_S3	Certain software maintenance products, third party services and extended warranties sold by the Company (for which the Com pany is not the primary obligor) are recognized on a net basis.
945983_11_ITEM15_P54_S4	Accordingly, such revenues are recognized in net sales either at the time of sale or over the contract period, based on the nature of the contract, at the net amount retained by the Company, with no cost of goods sold.
945983_11_ITEM15_P55_S0	Vendor rebates and price protection are recorded when earned as a reduction to cost of sales or merchandise inventory, as applicable.
945983_11_ITEM15_P55_S1	Cooperative reimbursements from vendors, which are earned and available, are recorded in the period the related advertising expenditure is incurred.
945983_11_ITEM15_P55_S2	Cooperative reimbursements are recorded as net sales in accordance with ASC Topic 605-50 Accounting by a Customer (including reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a Vendor.

945983_11_ITEM15_P56_S1	Stock- based compensation is recognized based on the grant date fair value and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is generally the vesting period.
945983_11_ITEM15_P57_S0	The Company utilizes the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
945983_11_ITEM15_P57_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
945983_11_ITEM15_P57_S2	This method also requires a valuation allowance against the net deferred tax asset if, based on the weighted available evidence, it is more likely than not that some or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.

945983_11_ITEM15_P64_S0	Estimated fair values of marketable securities are based on quoted market prices.
945983_11_ITEM15_P65_S0	The Company accounts for the fair value measurements in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 820 Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure , which establishes a framework for measuring fair value under generally accepted accounting principles and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
945983_11_ITEM15_P65_S1	The Company uses the following methods for determining fair value in accordance with ASC Topic 820.
945983_11_ITEM15_P66_S0	For assets and liabilities that are measured using quoted prices in active markets for the identical asset or liability, the total fair value is the published market price per unit multiplied by the number of units held without consideration of transaction costs (Level 1).
945983_11_ITEM15_P66_S1	Assets and liabilities that are measured using significant other observable inputs are valued by reference to similar assets or liabilities, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities, quoted prices in markets that are not active, or othe r inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data (Level 2).
945983_11_ITEM15_P66_S2	For all remaining assets and liabilities for which there are no significant observable inputs, fair value is derived using an assessment of various discount rates, default risk, credit quality and the overall capital market liquidity (Level 3).
945983_11_ITEM15_P67_S0	The following table summarizes the basis used to measure certain financial assets and liabilities at fair value on a recurring basis in the consolidated balance sheet:
945983_11_ITEM15_P68_S0	U.S. Government Securities - U.S. government securities are valued using quoted market prices.
945983_11_ITEM15_P68_S1	Accordingly, U.S. government securities are categorized in Level 1 of the fair value hierarchy.
945983_11_ITEM15_P69_S0	The fair value of certificates of deposit is estimated using third-party quotations.
945983_11_ITEM15_P69_S1	These deposits are categorized in Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy.

945983_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. (the Company, us, we, or our ) is an information technology ( IT ) channel company.
945983_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	We resell software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States and Canada.
945983_12_ITEM1_P0_S2	We also distribute software through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_12_ITEM1_P0_S3	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization, networking, software development, database modeling, security, and other technically sophisticated domains.
945983_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.
945983_12_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our Common Stock is listed on The Nasdaq Global Market under the symbol WSTG .
945983_12_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our main web site address is www.waysidetechnology.com, and the other web sites maintained by our business include www.lifeboatdistribution.com, and www.techxtend.com.
945983_12_ITEM1_P1_S3	Reference to these uniform resource locators or URLs is made as an inactive textual reference for informational purposes only.
945983_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	Information on our web sites should not be considered filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and is not, and should not be deemed to be, a part of this report.
945983_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Company operates through two segments, Lifeboat Distribution ( Lifeboat ) and the TechXtend ( TechXtend ) segment (formerly the Programmer s Paradise segment).
945983_12_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Lifeboat segment distributes technical software through a worldwide network of corporate and value-added resellers, consultants, and systems integrators.
945983_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	The TechXtend segment sells technical software, hardware, and services for microcomputers, servers, and networks to individual programmers, corporations, government agencies, and educational institutions primarily in the United States and Canada.
945983_12_ITEM1_P4_S1	For each of our segments, revenues from unaffiliated customers, income and total assets, among other financial information, is presented in Note 10 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
945983_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	The software market is highly competitive.
945983_12_ITEM1_P5_S1	Pricing is very aggressive in both software distribution and reselling.
945983_12_ITEM1_P5_S2	The Company expects pricing pressure to continue.
945983_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company faces competition from a wide variety of sources.
945983_12_ITEM1_P6_S1	In the Lifeboat segment, we compete against much larger broad-line distributors, as well as specialty distributors and, in some cases, the direct sales teams of the vendors we represent also sell directly to the end-customers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P6_S2	In the TechXtend segment, we also compete against vendors who sell directly to customers, as well as software resellers, superstores, e-commerce vendors, and other direct marketers of software products.
945983_12_ITEM1_P6_S3	In both segments, some of our competitors are significantly larger and have substantially greater resources than the Company.
945983_12_ITEM1_P6_S4	Many of our competitors compete principally on the basis of price, product availability, customer service and technical support.
945983_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	There can be no assurance that the Company can compete effectively against existing competitors or new competitors that may enter the market or that it can generate profit margins which represent a fair return to the Company.
945983_12_ITEM1_P7_S1	In addition, price is an important competitive factor in the personal computer software market and there can be no assurance that the Company will not be subject to increased price competition.
945983_12_ITEM1_P7_S2	An increase in the amount of competition faced by the Company, or its failure to compete effectively against its competitors, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations.
945983_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company competes to attract prospective buyers and in sourcing new products from software developers and publishers, as well as in marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	believes that its ability to offer software developers and IT professionals a wide selection of products at reasonable prices with prompt delivery and high customer service levels, along with its good relationships with vendors and suppliers, allows it to compete effectively in acquiring prospective buyers and marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	The Company competes to gain distribution rights for new products primarily on the basis of its reputation and its relationships with software publishers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	The market for developer and infrastructure software products is characterized by rapid changes in technology, user requirements, and customer specifications.
945983_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	The manner in which software products are distributed and sold is changing, and new methods of distribution and sale may emerge or expand.
945983_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	Software developers and publishers have sold, and may intensify their efforts to sell, their products directly to end-users.
945983_12_ITEM1_P11_S3	The continuing evolution of the Internet as a platform in which to conduct e-commerce business transactions has both lowered the barriers for competition and broadened customer access to products and information, increasing competition and reducing prices.
945983_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	From time to time, certain software developers and publishers have instituted programs for the direct sale of large order quantities of software to certain major corporate accounts.
945983_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	These types of programs may continue to be developed and used by various developers and publishers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	While Microsoft and other vendors currently sell new releases or upgrades directly to end users, they have not, however, attempted to completely bypass the reseller channel.
945983_12_ITEM1_P13_S1	There can be no assurances, that software developers and publishers will continue using resellers to the same extent they currently do.
945983_12_ITEM1_P13_S2	Future efforts by software developers and publishers to bypass third- party sales channels could materially and adversely affect the Company s business operations and financial conditions.
945983_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	In addition, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services.
945983_12_ITEM1_P14_S1	Any of these competitive programs, if successful, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_12_ITEM1_P14_S2	For a description of additional risks relating to competition in our industry, please refer to Item 1.A. Risk Factors : We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell , and The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business .
945983_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	The Company offers a wide variety of products from a broad range of publishers and manufacturers, including CA Technologies Inc., Quest Software, Inc., Intel Corporation, Vmware, TechSmith Corporation, Flexera Corp., Acronis, Solarwinds, Astaro, and Veeam Corporation.
945983_12_ITEM1_P15_S1	On a continuous basis, we screen new products for inclusion in our catalogs and web sites based on their features, quality, price, profit margins and warranties, as well as on current sales trends.
945983_12_ITEM1_P15_S2	Since the Company predominantly sells software, sales of hardware and peripherals represented only 4%, 4% and 7%, of our overall revenue in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
945983_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	We market products through creative marketing communications, including our web sites, local and on-line seminars, print and electronic catalogs.
945983_12_ITEM1_P16_S1	We also use direct e-mail and printed material to introduce new products and upgrades, to cross-sell products to current customers, and to educate and inform existing and potential customers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P16_S2	We believe that our blend of electronic and traditional marketing and selling programs are important marketing vehicles for software publishers and manufacturers.
945983_12_ITEM1_P16_S3	These programs provide a cost-effective and service-oriented means to market and sell and fulfill software products and meet the needs of users.
945983_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	The Company had three customers that accounted for more than 10% of total sales for 2011.
945983_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2011, CDW Corporation, Insight and Software House International accounted for 14.0%, 11.0% and 10.5%, respectively, of consolidated net sales and, as of December 31, 2011, 12.4%, 6.8%, and 4.7%, respectively, of total net accounts receivable.
945983_12_ITEM1_P17_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2010, CDW Corporation accounted for 15.8% of consolidated net sales.

945983_12_ITEM1_P26_S0	In 2011, the Company purchased approximately 90% of its products directly from manufacturers and publishers and the balance from multiple distributors, as compared to 90% in 2010, and 85% in 2009.
945983_12_ITEM1_P26_S1	Most suppliers or distributors will drop ship products directly to the customers, which reduces physical handling by the Company.
945983_12_ITEM1_P27_S0	Inventory management techniques, such as drop shipping allow the Company to offer a greater range of products without increased inventory requirements or associated risk.
945983_12_ITEM1_P28_S0	Inventory levels may vary from period to period, due in part to increases or decreases in sales levels, the Company s practice of making large-volume purchases when it deems the terms of such purchases to be attractive, and the addition of new suppliers and products.
945983_12_ITEM1_P28_S1	Moreover, the Company s order fulfillment and inventory control systems allow the Company to order certain products just in time for next day shipping.
945983_12_ITEM1_P28_S2	The Company promotes the use of electronic data interchange ( EDI ) with its suppliers, which helps reduce overhead and the use of paper in the ordering process.
945983_12_ITEM1_P29_S0	individual products are important to our business, we believe that competitive sources of supply are available for substantially all of the product categories we carry.

945983_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should carefully consider the risk factors set forth below as well as the other information contained in this report.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or those currently viewed by us to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Changes in the information technology industry and/or economic environment may reduce demand for the products and services we sell.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our results of operations are influenced by a variety of factors, including the condition of the IT industry, general economic conditions, shifts in demand for, or availability of, computer products and software and IT services and industry introductions of new products, upgrades or methods of distribution.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The information technology products industry is characterized by abrupt changes in technology, rapid changes in customer preferences, short product life cycles and evolving industry standards.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Net sales can be dependent on demand for specific product categories, and any change in demand for or supply of such products could have a material adverse effect on our net sales, and/or cause us to record write-downs of obsolete inventory, if we fail to react in a timely manner to such changes.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We acquire products for resale both directly from manufacturers and indirectly from distributors.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The loss of a supplier could cause a disruption in the availability of products.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Additionally, there is no assurance that as manufacturers continue to or increasingly sell directly to end users and through the distribution channel, that they will not limit or curtail the availability of their products to resellers like us.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S4	For example, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services, and correspondingly, decrease the volume of products sold through us.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Our inability to obtain a sufficient quantity of products, or an allocation of products from a manufacturer in a way that favors one of our competitors, or competing distribution channels, relative to us, could cause us to be unable to fill clients orders in a timely manner, or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S6	We also rely on our suppliers to provide funds for us to market their products, including through our catalogs and on-line marketing efforts, and to provide purchasing incentives to us.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P3_S7	If any of the suppliers that have historically provided these benefits to us decides to reduce such benefits, our expenses would increase, adversely affecting our results of operations.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Lingering Effects of the Recent Economic Downturn May Reduce our Revenues and Profits.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	adoption of new technologies and increased price competition.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	We may, therefore, experience a greater decline in demand for the products we sell, resulting in increased competition and pressure to reduce the cost of operations.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Any benefits from cost reductions may take longer to realize and may not fully mitigate the impact of the reduced demand.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition, weak financial and credit markets heighten the risk of customer bankruptcies and create a corresponding delay in collecting receivables from those customers and may also affect our vendors ability to supply products, which could disrupt our operations.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P5_S4	The realization of any or all of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Competition has been based primarily on price, product availability, speed of delivery, credit availability and quality and breadth of product lines and, increasingly, also is based on the ability to tailor specific solutions to client needs.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We compete with manufacturers, including manufacturers of products we sell, as well as a large number and wide variety of marketers and resellers of IT products and services.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	In addition, manufacturers are increasing the volume of software products they distribute electronically directly to end-users and in the future will likely pay lower referral fees for sales of certain software licensing agreements sold by us.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Generally, pricing is very aggressive in the industry, and we expect pricing pressures to continue.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P7_S1	There can be no assurance that we will be able to negotiate prices as favorable as those negotiated by our competitors or that we will be able to offset the effects of price reductions with an increase in the number of clients, higher net sales, cost reductions, or greater sales of services, which service sales typically at higher gross margins, or otherwise.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Price reductions by our competitors that we either cannot or choose not to match could result in an erosion of our market share and/or reduced sales or, to the extent we match such reductions, could result in reduced operating margins, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Disruptions in our information technology and voice and data networks could affect our ability to service our clients and cause us to incur additional expenses.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We believe that our success to date has been, and future results of operations likely will be, dependent in large part upon our ability to provide prompt and efficient service to clients.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Our ability to provide such services is dependent largely on the accuracy, quality and utilization of the information generated by our IT systems, which affect our ability to manage our sales, client service, distribution, inventories and accounting systems and the reliability of our voice and data networks.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We depend on certain key personnel.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Our future success will be largely dependent on the efforts of key management personnel.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P9_S2	We also believe that our future success will be largely dependent on our continued ability to attract and retain highly qualified management, sales, service and technical personnel.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P9_S3	We cannot assure you that we will be able to attract and retain such personnel.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Further, we make a significant investment in the training of our sales account executives.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P9_S5	Our inability to retain such personnel or to train them either rapidly enough to meet our expanding needs or in an effective manner for quickly changing market conditions could cause a decrease in the overall quality and efficiency of our sales staff, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Risks Related to Our Common Stock .
945983_12_ITEM1A_P10_S1	The exercise of outstanding options or any other issuance of shares by us may dilute your ownership of our Common Stock.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Our Common Stock is thinly traded.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P10_S3	As a result of the thin trading market for our stock, its market price may fluctuate significantly more than the stock market as a whole or of the stock prices of similar companies.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P10_S4	Without a larger float, our common stock will be less liquid than the stock of companies with broader public ownership, and, as a result, the trading prices for our Common Stock may be more volatile.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	small volume of our Common Stock may have a greater impact on the trading price of our stock than would be the case if our public float were larger.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our common stock is listed on The Nasdaq Global Market, and we therefore are subject to continued listing requirements, include requirements with respect to the market value and number of publicly-held shares, number of stockholders, minimum bid price, number of market makers and either (i) stockholders equity or (ii) total market value of stock, total assets and total revenues.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	If we fail to satisfy one or more of the requirements, we may be delisted from The Nasdaq Global Market.
945983_12_ITEM1A_P12_S2	If we are delisted from The Nasdaq Global Market, we do not qualify for listing on The Nasdaq Capital Market, and if we are not able to list our common stock on another exchange, our common stock could be quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board or on the pink sheets .
945983_12_ITEM1A_P12_S3	As a result, we could face significant adverse consequences including, among others, a limited availability of market quotations for our securities and a decreased ability to issue additional securities or obtain additional financing in the future.

945983_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	In June 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board, FASB issued ASU 2011-05, Presentation of Comprehensive Income , an amendment to FASB ASC Topic 220, Comprehensive Income .
945983_12_ITEM7_P46_S1	The update gives companies the option to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements.
945983_12_ITEM7_P46_S2	The amendments in the update do not change the items that must be reported in other comprehensive income or when an item of other comprehensive income must be reclassified to net income.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	The ASU is effective for the Company for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2011.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S1	In December 2011, the FASB issued ASU 2011-12 Deferral of the Effective Date for Amendments to the Presentation of Reclassifications of Items out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income in Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-05.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S2	This update stated that the specific requirement to present items that are reclassified from other comprehensive income to net income alongside their respective components of net income and other comprehensive income will be deferred.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S3	All other requirements of ASU 2011-05 will be required to be adopted.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S4	The amendments should be applied retrospectively for all prior periods presented.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S5	Early adoption is permitted because compliance with the amendments is already permitted.
945983_12_ITEM7_P47_S6	The Company does not expect the adoption of these provisions to have a material impact on our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.

945983_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	The Company believes the following critical accounting policies used in the preparation of its consolidated financial statements affect its more significant judgments and estimates.
945983_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of its customers to make required payments.
945983_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	If the financial condition of the Company s customers were to deteriorate, resulting in an impairment of their ability to make payments, additional allowances may be required.
945983_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company writes down its inventory for estimated obsolescence or unmarketable inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
945983_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	If actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, additional inventory write-offs may be required.
945983_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Company has considered future taxable income and ongoing prudent and feasible tax planning strategies in assessing the need for the valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets.
945983_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	In the event the Company were to determine that it would not be able to realize all or part of its net deferred tax assets in the future, an adjustment to the deferred tax assets would be charged to income in the period such determination was made.
945983_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	Under the fair value recognition provision, stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is the vesting period.
945983_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	We make certain assumptions in order to value and expense our various share-based payment awards.
945983_12_ITEM7_P70_S1	In connection with valuing stock options, we use the Black-Scholes model, which requires us to estimate certain subjective assumptions.
945983_12_ITEM7_P70_S2	The key assumptions we make are: the expected volatility of our stock; the expected term of the award; and the expected forfeiture rate.
945983_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	In connection with our restricted stock programs we make assumptions principally related to the forfeiture rate.
945983_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	We review our valuation assumptions periodically and, as a result, we may change our valuation assumptions used to value stock based awards granted in future periods.
945983_12_ITEM7_P71_S2	Such changes may lead to a significant change in the expense we recognize in connection with share-based payments.

945983_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	As required by Rule 13a-15(b) under the Exchange Act, our management carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures , as such term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act, as of the end of the period covered by this report.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P0_S2	This evaluation was carried out under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our Company s President, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer (principal executive officer) and Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer (principal financial officer).
945983_12_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Based upon that evaluation, the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer concluded that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective, as of the end of the period covered by this report, to ensure that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms and is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management, including the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) of the Exchange Act.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, and effected by the Board of Directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Internal control over financial reporting includes maintaining records in reasonable detail that accurately and fairly reflect our transactions and disposition of assets; providing reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of our financial statements in accordance with GAAP; providing reasonable assurance that receipts and expenditures of the Company, are made in accordance of with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and providing reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Company assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P1_S4	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting is not intended to provide absolute assurance that a misstatement of our financial statements would be prevented or detected.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P1_S5	In addition, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that, owing to changes in conditions, controls may become inadequate, or that the degree of compliance with policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Based on this evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2011.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P2_S2	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2011 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P3_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
945983_12_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s registered public accounting firm.

945983_12_ITEM15_P27_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries, the Company, markets software to software development and information technology professionals in the United States and Canada.
945983_12_ITEM15_P27_S1	It was formerly known as Programmer s Paradise, Inc. and changed its name to Wayside Technology Group, Inc. in August 2006.
945983_12_ITEM15_P28_S0	The Company operates through two segments the TechXtend segment (formerly the Programmer s Paradise segment), which sells technical software, hardware and services directly to end-users (such as individual programmers, corporations, government agencies, and educational institutions) and the Lifeboat segment, which distributes technical software to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators.
945983_12_ITEM15_P29_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
945983_12_ITEM15_P29_S1	All intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated.
945983_12_ITEM15_P30_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make extensive use of certain estimates and assumptions which affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting periods.
945983_12_ITEM15_P30_S1	The significant areas of estimation include but are not limited to accounting for allowance for uncollectible accounts, sales returns, inventory valuation and obsolescence, income taxes, depreciation, contingencies, stock-based compensation.
945983_12_ITEM15_P30_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
945983_12_ITEM15_P31_S0	The Company calculates earnings per share in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 260, Earnings Per Share .
945983_12_ITEM15_P31_S1	Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of Common Stock outstanding during the period.
945983_12_ITEM15_P31_S2	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding, adjusted for potentially dilutive securities.
