945983_15_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should carefully consider the risk factors set forth below as well as the other information contained in this report.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or those currently viewed by us to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Changes in the information technology industry and/or economic environment may reduce demand for the products and services we sell.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our results of operations are influenced by a variety of factors, including the condition of the IT industry, general economic conditions, shifts in demand for, or availability of, computer products and software and IT services and industry introductions of new products, upgrades or methods of distribution.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The information technology products industry is characterized by abrupt changes in technology, rapid changes in customer preferences, short product life cycles and evolving industry standards.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Net sales can be dependent on demand for specific product categories, and any change in demand for or supply of such products could have a material adverse effect on our net sales, and/or cause us to record write-downs of obsolete inventory, if we fail to react in a timely manner to such changes.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We acquire products for resale both directly from manufacturers and indirectly from distributors.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The loss of a supplier could cause a disruption in the availability of products.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Additionally, there is no assurance that as manufacturers continue to or increasingly sell directly to end users and through the distribution channel, that they will not limit or curtail the availability of their products to distributors/resellers like us.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S4	For example, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services, and correspondingly, decrease the volume of products sold through us.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Our inability to obtain a sufficient quantity of products, or an allocation of products from a manufacturer in a way that favors one of our competitors, or competing distribution channels, relative to us, could cause us to be unable to fill clients orders in a timely manner, or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S6	We also rely on our suppliers to provide funds for us to market their products, including through our catalogs and on-line marketing efforts, and to provide purchasing incentives to us.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P3_S7	If any of the suppliers that have historically provided these benefits to us decides to reduce such benefits, our expenses would increase, adversely affecting our results of operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P4_S0	General economic weakness may reduce our revenues and profits.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The ongoing effects of the general economic downturn, especially outside of the USA, continues to cause some of our current and potential customers to delay or reduce technology purchases, resulting in longer sales cycles, slower adoption of new technologies and increased price competition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We may, therefore, experience a greater decline in demand for the products we sell, resulting in increased competition and pressure to reduce the cost of operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Any benefits from cost reductions may take longer to realize and may not fully mitigate the impact of the reduced demand.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P5_S0	may also affect our vendors ability to supply products, which could disrupt our operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P5_S1	The realization of any or all of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We Depend on Having Creditworthy Customers to Avoid an Adverse Impact to Our Operating Results and Financial Condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We require sufficient amounts of debt and equity capital to fund our transactions as we provide larger extended payment terms to certain of our customers.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P6_S2	If the credit quality of our customer base materially decreases, or if we experience a material increase in our credit losses, we may find it difficult to continue to obtain the required capital for our business, and our operating results and financial condition may be harmed.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P6_S3	In addition to the impact on our ability to attract capital, a material increase in our delinquency and default experience would itself have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P6_S4	Furthermore, if any of our customers to whom we provide larger extended payment terms go elsewhere for financing, such loss of financing revenue could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Competition has been based primarily on price, product availability, speed of delivery, credit availability and quality and breadth of product lines and, increasingly, also is based on the ability to tailor specific solutions to client needs.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P7_S2	We compete with manufacturers, including manufacturers of products we sell, as well as a large number and wide variety of marketers and resellers of IT products and services.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P7_S3	In addition, manufacturers are increasing the volume of software products they distribute electronically directly to end-users and in the future will likely pay lower referral fees for sales of certain software licensing agreements sold by us.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Generally, pricing is very aggressive in the industry, and we expect pricing pressures to continue.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P8_S1	There can be no assurance that we will be able to negotiate prices as favorable as those negotiated by our competitors or that we will be able to offset the effects of price reductions with an increase in the number of clients, higher net sales, cost reductions, or greater sales of services, which service sales typically at higher gross margins, or otherwise.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Price reductions by our competitors that we either cannot or choose not to match could result in an erosion of our market share and/or reduced sales or, to the extent we match such reductions, could result in reduced operating margins, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Disruptions in our information technology and voice and data networks could affect our ability to service our clients and cause us to incur additional expenses.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P9_S1	We believe that our success to date has been, and future results of operations likely will be, dependent in large part upon our ability to provide prompt and efficient service to clients.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Our ability to provide such services is dependent largely on the accuracy, quality and utilization of the information generated by our IT systems, which affect our ability to manage our sales, client service, distribution, inventories and accounting systems and the reliability of our voice and data networks.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Failure to adequately maintain the security of our electronic and other confidential information could materially adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We are dependent upon automated information technology processes.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Privacy, security, and compliance concerns have continued to increase as technology has evolved to facilitate commerce and as cross-border commerce increases.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P12_S0	As part of our normal business activities, we collect and store certain confidential information, including personal information of employees and information about partners and clients which may be entitled to protection under a number of regulatory regimes.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In the course of normal and customary business practice, we may share some of this information with vendors who assist us with certain aspects of our business.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Moreover, the success of our operations depends upon the secure transmission of confidential and personal data over public networks, including the use of cashless payments.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P13_S0	disruption, damage to our reputation, financial obligations to third parties, fines, penalties, regulatory proceedings and private litigation with potentially large costs, and also result in deterioration in our employees , partners and clients confidence in us and other competitive disadvantages, and thus could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P13_S1	During 2014 and 2013 we did not have any cybersecurity breaches.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We depend on certain key personnel.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Our future success will be largely dependent on the efforts of key management personnel for strategic and operational guidance as well as relationships with our key vendors and customers.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P14_S2	We also believe that our future success will be largely dependent on our continued ability to attract and retain highly qualified management, sales, service, finance and technical personnel.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P14_S3	We cannot assure you that we will be able to attract and retain such personnel.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Further, we make a significant investment in the training of our sales account executives.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P14_S5	Our inability to retain such personnel or to train them either rapidly enough to meet our expanding needs or in an effective manner for quickly changing market conditions could cause a decrease in the overall quality and efficiency of our sales staff, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Risks Related to Our Common Stock .
945983_15_ITEM1A_P15_S1	The exercise of outstanding options or any other issuance of shares by us may dilute your ownership of our Common Stock.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Our Common Stock is thinly traded, which may be exacerbated by our repurchases of our Common Stock.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P15_S3	As a result of the thin trading market for our stock, its market price may fluctuate significantly more than the stock market as a whole or of the stock prices of similar companies.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P15_S4	Without a larger float, our common stock will be less liquid than the stock of companies with broader public ownership, and, as a result, the trading prices for our Common Stock may be more volatile.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P15_S5	Among other things, trading of a relatively small volume of our Common Stock may have a greater impact on the trading price of our stock than would be the case if our public float were larger.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our common stock is listed on The NASDAQ Global Market, and we therefore are subject to continued listing requirements, including requirements with respect to the market value and number of publicly-held shares, number of stockholders, minimum bid price, number of market makers and either (i) stockholders equity or (ii) total market value of stock, total assets and total revenues.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P16_S1	If we fail to satisfy one or more of the requirements, we may be delisted from The NASDAQ Global Market.
945983_15_ITEM1A_P16_S2	If we do not qualify for listing on The NASDAQ Capital Market, and if we are not able to list our common stock on another exchange, our common stock could be quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board or on the pink sheets .
945983_15_ITEM1A_P16_S3	As a result, we could face significant adverse consequences including, among others, a limited availability of market quotations for our securities and a decreased ability to issue additional securities or obtain additional financing in the future.

945983_15_ITEM7_P46_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued guidance for revenue recognition for contracts, superseding the previous revenue recognition requirements, along with most existing industry-specific guidance.
945983_15_ITEM7_P46_S1	The guidance requires an entity to review contracts in five steps: 1) identify the contract, 2) identify performance obligations, 3) determine the transaction price, 4) allocate the transaction price, and 5) recognize revenue.
945983_15_ITEM7_P46_S2	The new standard will result in enhanced disclosures regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue arising from contracts with customers.
945983_15_ITEM7_P46_S3	The standard is effective for our reporting year beginning January 1, 2017 and early adoption is not permitted.
945983_15_ITEM7_P46_S4	We are currently evaluating the impact of this new accounting pronouncement, if any; the pronouncement will have on our consolidated financial statements.

945983_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Company bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
945983_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
945983_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company believes the following critical accounting policies used in the preparation of its consolidated financial statements affect its more significant judgments and estimates.
945983_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of its customers to make required payments.
945983_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	If the financial condition of the Company s customers were to deteriorate, resulting in an impairment of their ability to make payments, additional allowances may be required.
945983_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	The Company writes down its inventory for estimated obsolescence or unmarketable inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
945983_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	If actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, additional inventory write-offs may be required.
945983_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	The Company has considered future taxable income and ongoing prudent and feasible tax planning strategies in assessing the need for the valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets.
945983_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	In the event the Company were to determine that it would not be able to realize all or part of its net deferred tax assets in the future, an adjustment to the deferred tax assets would be charged to income in the period such determination was made.
945983_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	Under the fair value recognition provision, stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is the vesting period.
945983_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	We make certain assumptions in order to value and expense our various share-based payment awards.
945983_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	In connection with valuing stock options, we use the Black-Scholes model, which requires us to estimate certain subjective assumptions.
945983_15_ITEM7_P72_S2	The key assumptions we make are: the expected volatility of our stock; the expected term of the award; and the expected forfeiture rate.
945983_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	In connection with our restricted stock programs we make assumptions principally related to the forfeiture rate.
945983_15_ITEM7_P73_S1	We review our valuation assumptions periodically and, as a result, we may change our valuation assumptions used to value stock based awards granted in future periods.
945983_15_ITEM7_P73_S2	Such changes may lead to a significant change in the expense we recognize in connection with share-based payments.

945983_15_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P0_S1	As required by Rule 13a-15(b) under the Exchange Act, our management carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures , as such term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act, as of the end of the period covered by this report.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P0_S2	This evaluation was carried out under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our Company s President, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer (principal executive officer) and Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer (principal financial officer).
945983_15_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Based upon that evaluation, the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer concluded that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective, as of the end of the period covered by this report, to ensure that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms and is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management, including the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Interim Chief Accounting Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) of the Exchange Act.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, and effected by the Board of Directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Internal control over financial reporting includes maintaining records in reasonable detail that accurately and fairly reflect our transactions and disposition of assets; providing reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of our financial statements in accordance with GAAP; providing reasonable assurance that receipts and expenditures of the Company, are made in accordance of with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and providing reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Company assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting is not intended to provide absolute assurance that a misstatement of our financial statements would be prevented or detected.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P3_S3	In addition, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that, owing to changes in conditions, controls may become inadequate, or that the degree of compliance with policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( 2013 Framework).
945983_15_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Based on this evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2014.
945983_15_ITEM9A_P4_S2	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2014 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.

945983_15_ITEM15_P37_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries (the Company ), was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.
945983_15_ITEM15_P37_S1	The Company distributes software developed by others through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_15_ITEM15_P37_S2	We also resell computer software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States of America ( USA ) and Canada.
945983_15_ITEM15_P37_S3	We also operate a sales branch in Europe to serve our customers in this region of the world.
945983_15_ITEM15_P37_S4	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_15_ITEM15_P38_S0	The Company is organized into two reportable operating segments.
945983_15_ITEM15_P39_S0	The Lifeboat Distribution segment distributes technical software to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators worldwide.
945983_15_ITEM15_P40_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.
945983_15_ITEM15_P41_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
945983_15_ITEM15_P41_S1	All intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated.
945983_15_ITEM15_P42_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( US GAAP ) requires management to make extensive use of certain estimates and assumptions which affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting periods.
945983_15_ITEM15_P42_S1	The significant areas of estimation include but are not limited to accounting for allowance for doubtful accounts, sales returns, inventory obsolescence, income taxes, depreciation, contingencies and stock-based compensation.
945983_15_ITEM15_P42_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
945983_15_ITEM15_P43_S0	The Company calculates earnings per share in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board FASB ASC Topic 260, Earnings Per Share .
945983_15_ITEM15_P43_S1	Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of Common Stock outstanding during the period.
945983_15_ITEM15_P43_S2	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding, adjusted for potentially dilutive securities including unexercised stock option grants and nonvested shares of restricted stock.
945983_15_ITEM15_P44_S0	A reconciliation of the numerators and denominators of the basic and diluted per share computations follows:
945983_15_ITEM15_P45_S0	The Company considers all liquid short-term investments with original maturities of 90 days or less to be cash equivalents.
945983_15_ITEM15_P46_S0	Accounts receivable principally represents amounts collectible from our customers.
945983_15_ITEM15_P46_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers but generally does not require collateral to support any outstanding obligation.
945983_15_ITEM15_P47_S0	We provide allowances for doubtful accounts related to accounts receivable for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.
945983_15_ITEM15_P47_S1	We take into consideration the overall quality and aging of the receivable portfolio along with specifically identified customer risks.
945983_15_ITEM15_P47_S2	If actual customer payment performance were to deteriorate to an extent not expected, additional allowances may be required.
945983_15_ITEM15_P48_S0	We historically have a low write-off rate, especially on extended payment terms sales transactions.
945983_15_ITEM15_P48_S1	Write-offs on extended payment terms sales transactions as a percentage of net sales amounted to 0%, 0% and 0.033%, respectively, for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012.
945983_15_ITEM15_P49_S0	Assets and liabilities of the Company s foreign subsidiaries have been translated at current exchange rates, and related revenues and expenses have been translated at average rates of exchange in effect during the year.
945983_15_ITEM15_P49_S1	Cumulative translation adjustments have been classified within accumulated other comprehensive income, which is a separate component of stockholders equity in accordance FASB ASC Topic No. 220, Comprehensive Income .
945983_15_ITEM15_P50_S0	Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations in credit risk consist of cash and cash equivalents.
945983_15_ITEM15_P51_S0	The Company s cash and cash equivalents, at times, may exceed federally insured limits.
945983_15_ITEM15_P51_S1	The Company s cash and cash equivalents are deposited primarily in banking institutions with global operations.
945983_15_ITEM15_P51_S2	The Company has not experienced any losses in such accounts.
945983_15_ITEM15_P51_S3	The Company believes it is not exposed to any significant credit risk on cash and cash equivalents.
945983_15_ITEM15_P52_S0	The carrying amounts of financial instruments, including cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and accounts payable approximated fair value as of December 31, 2014 and 2013, because of the relative short maturity of these instruments.
945983_15_ITEM15_P52_S1	The Company s accounts receivable long-term is discounted to their present value at prevailing market rates so the balances approximate fair value.
945983_15_ITEM15_P53_S0	Inventory, consisting primarily of finished products held for resale, is stated at the lower of cost (weighted average) or market.
945983_15_ITEM15_P54_S0	Equipment and leasehold improvements are stated at cost.
945983_15_ITEM15_P54_S1	Equipment depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method over three to five years.
945983_15_ITEM15_P55_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized using the straight line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets or the related lease terms, whichever is shorter.
945983_15_ITEM15_P56_S0	Accounts receivable long-term result from product sales with extended payment terms that are discounted to their present values at the prevailing market rates.
945983_15_ITEM15_P56_S1	In subsequent periods, the accounts receivable are increased to the amounts due and payable by the customers through the accretion of interest income on the unpaid accounts receivable due in future years.
945983_15_ITEM15_P56_S2	The amounts under these long-term accounts receivable due within one year are reclassified to the current portion of accounts receivable.
945983_15_ITEM15_P57_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income for the period, the impact of unrealized foreign currency translation adjustments and unrealized gains or losses on available-for-sale marketable securities.
945983_15_ITEM15_P57_S1	The foreign currency translation adjustments are not currently adjusted for income taxes as they relate to permanent investments in international subsidiaries.
945983_15_ITEM15_P58_S0	Revenue on product (software and hardware) and maintenance agreement sales are recognized once four criteria are met: (1) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (2) the price is fixed and determinable, (3) delivery (software and hardware) or fulfillment (maintenance) has occurred, and (4) there is reasonable assurance of collection of the sales proceeds.
945983_15_ITEM15_P58_S1	Revenues from the sales of hardware products, software products and licenses and maintenance agreements are recognized on a gross basis with the selling price to the customer recorded as sales and the acquisition cost of the product recorded as cost of sales.
945983_15_ITEM15_P59_S0	Product delivery to customers occur in a variety of ways, including (i) as physical product shipped from the Company s warehouse, (ii) via drop-shipment by the vendor, or (iii) via electronic delivery for software licenses.
945983_15_ITEM15_P59_S1	The Company leverages drop-ship arrangements with many of its vendors and suppliers to deliver products to customers without having to physically hold the inventory at its warehouse, thereby increasing efficiency and reducing costs.
945983_15_ITEM15_P60_S0	The Company recognizes revenue for drop-ship arrangements on a gross basis.
945983_15_ITEM15_P60_S1	Furthermore, in such drop-ship arrangements, the Company negotiates price with the customer, pays the supplier directly for the product shipped and bears credit risk of collecting payment from its customers.
945983_15_ITEM15_P60_S2	The Company serves as the principal with the customer and, therefore, recognizes the sale and cost of sale of the product upon receiving notification from the supplier that the product has shipped.
945983_15_ITEM15_P61_S0	Maintenance agreements allow customers to obtain technical support directly from the software publisher and to upgrade, at no additional cost, to the latest technology if new applications are introduced by the software publisher during the period that the maintenance agreement is in effect.
945983_15_ITEM15_P62_S0	Sales are recorded net of discounts, rebates, and returns.
945983_15_ITEM15_P62_S1	Vendor rebates and price protection are recorded when earned as a reduction to cost of sales or merchandise inventory, as applicable.
945983_15_ITEM15_P63_S0	Cooperative reimbursements from vendors, which are earned and available, are recorded in the period the related advertising expenditure is incurred.
945983_15_ITEM15_P63_S1	Cooperative reimbursements are recorded as a reduction of cost of sales in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 605-50 Accounting by a Customer (including reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a Vendor.
945983_15_ITEM15_P63_S2	Provisions for returns are estimated based on historical sales returns and credit memo analysis which are adjusted to actual on a periodic basis.
945983_15_ITEM15_P64_S0	The Company has stockholder-approved stock incentive plans for employees and directors.
945983_15_ITEM15_P64_S1	Stock- based compensation is recognized based on the grant date fair value and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is generally the vesting period.
945983_15_ITEM15_P65_S0	The Company utilizes the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
945983_15_ITEM15_P65_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
945983_15_ITEM15_P65_S2	This method also requires a valuation allowance against the net deferred tax asset if, based on the weighted available evidence, it is more likely than not that some or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
945983_15_ITEM15_P66_S0	The Company s policy is to recognize interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions in income tax expense when assessed.
945983_15_ITEM15_P66_S1	The Company accounts for uncertainties in accordance with FASB ASC 740 Income Taxes .
945983_15_ITEM15_P66_S2	This standard clarified the accounting for uncertainties in income taxes.
945983_15_ITEM15_P66_S3	The standard prescribes criteria for recognition and measurement of tax positions.
945983_15_ITEM15_P66_S4	It also provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, and disclosures related to income taxes associated with uncertain tax positions.
945983_15_ITEM15_P67_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued guidance for revenue recognition for contracts, superseding the previous revenue recognition requirements, along with most existing industry-specific guidance.
945983_15_ITEM15_P67_S1	The guidance requires an entity to review contracts in five steps: 1) identify the contract, 2) identify performance obligations, 3) determine the transaction price, 4) allocate the transaction price, and 5) recognize revenue.
945983_15_ITEM15_P67_S2	The new standard will result in enhanced disclosures regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue arising from contracts with customers.
945983_15_ITEM15_P67_S3	The standard is effective for our reporting year beginning January 1, 2017 and early adoption is not permitted.
945983_15_ITEM15_P67_S4	We are currently evaluating the impact of this new accounting pronouncement, if any; the pronouncement will have on our consolidated financial statements.

945983_15_ITEM15_P79_S0	On January 4, 2013, the Company entered into a $10,000,000 revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) with Citibank, N.A. ( Citibank ) pursuant to a Business Loan Agreement (the Loan Agreement ), Promissory Note (the Note ), Commercial Security Agreements (the Security Agreements ) and Commercial Pledge Agreement (the Pledge Agreement ).
945983_15_ITEM15_P79_S1	The Credit Facility will be used for business and working capital purposes, including financing of larger extended payment terms sales transactions.
945983_15_ITEM15_P79_S2	The Credit Facility matures on January 4, 2016, at which time the Company must pay this loan in one payment of any outstanding principal plus all accrued unpaid interest.
945983_15_ITEM15_P79_S3	In addition, the Company will pay regular monthly payments of all accrued unpaid interest.
945983_15_ITEM15_P80_S0	The interest rate for any borrowings under the Credit Facility is subject to change from time to time based on the changes in an independent index which is the LIBOR Rate (the Index ).
945983_15_ITEM15_P80_S1	If the Index becomes unavailable during the term of this loan, Citibank may designate a substitute index after notifying the Company.
945983_15_ITEM15_P80_S2	Interest on the unpaid principal balance of the Note will be calculated using a rate of 1.500 percentage points over the Index.
945983_15_ITEM15_P81_S0	The Credit Facility is secured by the assets of the Company.
945983_15_ITEM15_P82_S0	Among other affirmative covenants set forth in the Loan Agreement, the Company must maintain (i) a ratio of Total Liabilities to Tangible Net Worth (each as defined in the Loan Agreement) of not greater than 2.50 to 1.00, to be tested quarterly and (ii) a minimum Debt Service Coverage Ratio (as defined in the Loan Agreement) of 2.00 to 1.00.
945983_15_ITEM15_P82_S1	Additionally, the Loan Agreement contains negative covenants related to, among other items, prohibitions against the creation of certain liens, engaging in any business activities substantially different than those currently engaged in by the Company, and paying dividends on the Company s stock other than (i) dividends payable in its stock and (ii) cash dividends in amounts and frequency consistent with past practice, without first securing the written consent of Citibank.
945983_15_ITEM15_P82_S2	The Company is in compliance with all covenants at December 31, 2014.
945983_15_ITEM15_P83_S0	At December 31, 2014, the Company had no borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facility.
945983_15_ITEM15_P83_S1	The Company had interest expense of $10 thousand related to the Credit Facility for the year ended December 31, 2013.

945983_15_ITEM15_P84_S1	The 1995 Plan, as amended on May 7, 1998, provides for the grant of options to purchase up to 1,137,500 shares of the Company s Common Stock to officers, directors, employees and consultants of the Company.

945983_15_ITEM15_P85_S1	The 1995 Director Plan, as amended on May 7, 1998, provides for the grant of options to purchase up to 187,500 shares of the Company s Common Stock to persons who are members of the Company s Board of Directors and not employees or officers of the Company.

945983_16_ITEM1_P0_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries (the Company, us, we, or our ) is an information technology ( IT ) channel company.
945983_16_ITEM1_P0_S1	We distribute software developed by others through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_16_ITEM1_P0_S2	We also resell computer software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States of America ( USA ) and Canada.
945983_16_ITEM1_P0_S3	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_16_ITEM1_P1_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.
945983_16_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our Common Stock is listed on The NASDAQ Global Market under the symbol WSTG .
945983_16_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our main web site address is www.waysidetechnology.com, and the other web sites maintained by our business include www.lifeboatdistribution.com, and www.techxtend.com.
945983_16_ITEM1_P1_S3	Reference to these uniform resource locators or URLs is made as an inactive textual reference for informational purposes only.
945983_16_ITEM1_P2_S0	Information on our web sites should not be considered filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and is not, and should not be deemed to be, a part of this report.
945983_16_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Company operates through two reportable operating segments.
945983_16_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Lifeboat Distribution segment distributes technical software to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators worldwide.
945983_16_ITEM1_P5_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.
945983_16_ITEM1_P5_S1	For each of our segments, sales from unaffiliated customers, income and total assets, among other financial information, is presented in Note 9 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
945983_16_ITEM1_P6_S0	The software market is highly competitive.
945983_16_ITEM1_P6_S1	Pricing is very aggressive in both software distribution and reselling.
945983_16_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company expects pricing pressure to continue.
945983_16_ITEM1_P7_S0	The Company faces competition from a wide variety of sources.
945983_16_ITEM1_P7_S1	In the Lifeboat Distribution segment, we compete against much larger broad-line distributors, as well as specialty distributors and, in some cases, the direct sales teams of the vendors we represent also sell directly to the end-customers.
945983_16_ITEM1_P7_S2	In the TechXtend segment, we also compete against vendors who sell directly to customers, as well as software resellers, superstores, e-commerce vendors, and other direct marketers of software and hardware products.
945983_16_ITEM1_P7_S3	In both segments, some of our competitors are significantly larger and have substantially greater resources than the Company.
945983_16_ITEM1_P7_S4	Many of our competitors compete principally on the basis of price, product availability, customer service and technical support.
945983_16_ITEM1_P8_S0	There can be no assurance that the Company can compete effectively against existing competitors or new competitors that may enter the market or that it can generate profit margins which represent a fair return to the Company.
945983_16_ITEM1_P8_S1	In addition, price is an important competitive factor in the personal computer software market and there can be no assurance that the Company will not be subject to increased price competition.
945983_16_ITEM1_P8_S2	An increase in the amount of competition faced by the Company, or its failure to compete effectively against its competitors, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1_P9_S0	The Company competes to attract prospective buyers and in sourcing new products from software developers and publishers, as well as in marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_16_ITEM1_P9_S1	The Company believes that its ability to offer software developers and IT professionals easy access to a wide selection of the right IT products at reasonable prices with prompt delivery and high customer service levels, along with its good relationships with vendors and suppliers, allows it to compete effectively in acquiring prospective buyers and marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_16_ITEM1_P10_S0	The Company competes to gain distribution rights for new products primarily on the basis of its reputation and its relationships with software publishers.
945983_16_ITEM1_P11_S0	The market for the software products we sell is characterized by rapid changes in technology, user requirements, and customer specifications.
945983_16_ITEM1_P11_S1	The manner in which software products are distributed and sold is changing, and new methods of distribution and sale may emerge or expand.
945983_16_ITEM1_P11_S2	Software developers and publishers have sold, and may intensify their efforts to sell, their products directly to end-users.
945983_16_ITEM1_P11_S3	The continuing evolution of the Internet as a platform in which to conduct e-commerce business transactions has both lowered the barriers for competition and broadened customer access to products and information, increasing competition and reducing prices.
945983_16_ITEM1_P12_S0	From time to time, certain software developers and publishers have instituted programs for the direct sale of large order quantities of software to certain major corporate accounts.
945983_16_ITEM1_P12_S1	These types of programs may continue to be developed and used by various developers and publishers.
945983_16_ITEM1_P13_S0	While software developers and publishers currently sell new releases or upgrades directly to end users, they have not attempted to completely bypass the distribution and reseller channels.
945983_16_ITEM1_P13_S1	There can be no assurances, however, that software developers and publishers will continue using distributors and resellers to the same extent they currently do.
945983_16_ITEM1_P13_S2	Future efforts by software developers and publishers to bypass third- party sales channels could materially and adversely affect the Company s business operations and financial conditions.
945983_16_ITEM1_P14_S0	In addition, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services.
945983_16_ITEM1_P14_S1	Any of these competitive programs, if successful, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1_P14_S2	For a description of additional risks relating to competition in our industry, please refer to Item 1.A. Risk Factors : We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell , and The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business .
945983_16_ITEM1_P15_S0	An essential part of our ongoing operations and growth plans is the continued recruitment of software publishers for which we can sell their products.

945983_16_ITEM1_P23_S1	The Company believes it enjoys good relationships with its vendors.
945983_16_ITEM1_P23_S2	The Company and its principal vendors have cooperated frequently in product introductions and in other marketing programs.
945983_16_ITEM1_P23_S3	As is customary in the industry, the Company has no long-term supply contracts with any of its suppliers.
945983_16_ITEM1_P23_S4	Substantially all of the Company s contracts with its vendors are terminable upon 30 days notice or less.
945983_16_ITEM1_P23_S5	Moreover, the manner in which software products are distributed and sold is changing, and new methods of distribution and sale may emerge or expand.
945983_16_ITEM1_P24_S0	Software publishers have sold, and may intensify their efforts to sell, their products directly to end-users.
945983_16_ITEM1_P25_S0	The Company s business and results of operations may be adversely affected if the terms and conditions of the Company s authorizations with its vendors were to be significantly modified or if certain products become unavailable to the Company.
945983_16_ITEM1_P26_S0	We believe that effective purchasing from a diverse vendor base is a key element of our business strategy.
945983_16_ITEM1_P26_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2015, Sophos was the only individual vendor from whom our purchases exceeded 10% of our total purchases and accounted for 24.2% of our total purchases.
945983_16_ITEM1_P26_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2014, Sophos was the only individual vendor from whom our purchases exceeded 10% of our total purchases and accounted for 14.7% of our total purchases.
945983_16_ITEM1_P26_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2013, Dell/Quest Software was the only individual vendor from whom our purchases exceeded 10% of our total purchases and accounted for 10.2% of our total purchases.
945983_16_ITEM1_P26_S4	The loss of a key vendor or group of vendors could disrupt our product availability and otherwise have an adverse effect on the Company.
945983_16_ITEM1_P27_S0	In 2015, the Company purchased approximately 96% of its products directly from manufacturers and publishers and the balance from multiple distributors, as compared to 95% and 93% in 2014 and 2013, respectively.
945983_16_ITEM1_P27_S1	Most suppliers or distributors will drop ship products directly to the customers, which reduces physical handling by the Company.
945983_16_ITEM1_P28_S0	Inventory management techniques, such as drop shipping allow the Company to offer a greater range of products without increased inventory requirements or associated risk.
945983_16_ITEM1_P29_S0	Inventory levels may vary from period to period, due in part to increases or decreases in sales levels, the Company s practice of making large-volume purchases when it deems the terms of such purchases to be attractive, and the addition of new suppliers and products.
945983_16_ITEM1_P29_S1	Moreover, the Company s order fulfillment and inventory control systems allow the Company to order certain products just in time for next day shipping.
945983_16_ITEM1_P29_S2	The Company promotes the use of electronic data interchange ( EDI ) with its suppliers, which helps reduce overhead and the use of paper in the ordering process.
945983_16_ITEM1_P30_S0	Although brand names and individual products are important to our business, we believe that competitive sources of supply are available for substantially all of the product categories we carry.
945983_16_ITEM1_P31_S0	The Company operates distribution facilities in Eatontown, New Jersey and Mississauga, Canada.
945983_16_ITEM1_P32_S0	The Company operates management information systems on Windows 2003 and Windows 2008 platforms that allow for centralized management of key functions, including inventory, accounts receivable, purchasing, sales and distribution.
945983_16_ITEM1_P33_S0	We are dependent on the accuracy and proper utilization of our information technology systems, including our telephone, web sites, e-mail and fax systems.
945983_16_ITEM1_P34_S0	The management information systems allow the Company to monitor sales trends, provide real-time product availability and order status information, track direct marketing campaign performance and to make marketing event driven purchasing decisions.
945983_16_ITEM1_P34_S1	In addition to the main system, the Company has systems of networked personal computers, as well as microcomputer-based desktop publishing systems, which facilitate data sharing and provide an automated office environment.
945983_16_ITEM1_P35_S0	The Company recognizes the need to continually upgrade its management information systems to most effectively manage its operations and customer database.
945983_16_ITEM1_P35_S1	In that regard, the Company anticipates that it will, from time to time, require software and hardware upgrades for its present management information systems.
945983_16_ITEM1_P36_S0	The Company conducts its business under various trademarks and service marks including Lifeboat Distribution and TechXtend.
945983_16_ITEM1_P36_S1	The Company protects these trademarks and service marks and believes that they have significant value to us and are important factors in our marketing programs.

945983_16_ITEM1_P37_S1	The Company is not a party to any collective bargaining agreements with its employees, has experienced no work stoppages and considers its relationships with its employees to be satisfactory.

945983_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should carefully consider the risk factors set forth below as well as the other information contained in this report.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or those currently viewed by us to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Changes in the information technology industry and/or economic environment may reduce demand for the products and services we sell.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our results of operations are influenced by a variety of factors, including the condition of the IT industry, general economic conditions, shifts in demand for, or availability of, computer products and software and IT services and industry introductions of new products, upgrades or methods of distribution.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The information technology products industry is characterized by abrupt changes in technology, rapid changes in customer preferences, short product life cycles and evolving industry standards.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Net sales can be dependent on demand for specific product categories, and any change in demand for or supply of such products could have a material adverse effect on our net sales, and/or cause us to record write-downs of obsolete inventory, if we fail to react in a timely manner to such changes.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We acquire products for resale both directly from manufacturers and indirectly from distributors.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The loss of a supplier could cause a disruption in the availability of products.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Additionally, there is no assurance that as manufacturers continue to or increasingly sell directly to end users and through the distribution channel, that they will not limit or curtail the availability of their products to distributors/resellers like us.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S4	For example, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services, and correspondingly, decrease the volume of products sold through us.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Our inability to obtain a sufficient quantity of products, or an allocation of products from a manufacturer in a way that favors one of our competitors, or competing distribution channels, relative to us, could cause us to be unable to fill clients orders in a timely manner, or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S6	We also rely on our suppliers to provide funds for us to market their products, including through our catalogs and on-line marketing efforts, and to provide purchasing incentives to us.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P3_S7	If any of the suppliers that have historically provided these benefits to us decides to reduce such benefits, our expenses would increase, adversely affecting our results of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	General economic weakness may reduce our revenues and profits.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The ongoing effects of the general economic downturn, especially outside of the USA, continues to cause some of our current and potential customers to delay or reduce technology purchases, resulting in longer sales cycles, slower adoption of new technologies and increased price competition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We may, therefore, experience a greater decline in demand for the products we sell, resulting in increased competition and pressure to reduce the cost of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Any benefits from cost reductions may take longer to realize and may not fully mitigate the impact of the reduced demand.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P4_S4	In addition, weak financial and credit markets heighten the risk of customer bankruptcies and create a corresponding delay in collecting receivables from those customers and may also affect our vendors ability to supply products, which could disrupt our operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P4_S5	The realization of any or all of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We depend on having creditworthy customers to avoid an adverse impact to our operating results and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P5_S1	We require sufficient amounts of debt and equity capital to fund our transactions as we provide larger extended payment terms to certain of our customers.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If the credit quality of our customer base materially decreases, or if we experience a material increase in our credit losses, we may find it difficult to continue to obtain the required capital for our business, and our operating results and financial condition may be harmed.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition to the impact on our ability to attract capital, a material increase in our delinquency and default experience would itself have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P5_S4	Furthermore, if any of our customers to whom we provide larger extended payment terms go elsewhere for financing, such loss of financing revenue could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Competition has been based primarily on price, product availability, speed of delivery, credit availability and quality and breadth of product lines and, increasingly, also is based on the ability to tailor specific solutions to client needs.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We compete with manufacturers, including manufacturers of products we sell, as well as a large number and wide variety of marketers and resellers of IT products and services.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P6_S3	In addition, manufacturers are increasing the volume of software products they distribute electronically directly to end-users and in the future will likely pay lower referral fees for sales of certain software licensing agreements sold by us.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Generally, pricing is very aggressive in the industry, and we expect pricing pressures to continue.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P7_S1	There can be no assurance that we will be able to negotiate prices as favorable as those negotiated by our competitors or that we will be able to offset the effects of price reductions with an increase in the number of clients, higher net sales, cost reductions, or greater sales of services, which service sales typically at higher gross margins, or otherwise.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Price reductions by our competitors that we either cannot or choose not to match could result in an erosion of our market share and/or reduced sales or, to the extent we match such reductions, could result in reduced operating margins, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Disruptions in our information technology and voice and data networks could affect our ability to service our clients and cause us to incur additional expenses.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We believe that our success to date has been, and future results of operations likely will be, dependent in large part upon our ability to provide prompt and efficient service to clients.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Our ability to provide such services is dependent largely on the accuracy, quality and utilization of the information generated by our IT systems, which affect our ability to manage our sales, client service, distribution, inventories and accounting systems and the reliability of our voice and data networks.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Failure to adequately maintain the security of our electronic and other confidential information could materially adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We are dependent upon automated information technology processes.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	As part of our normal business activities, we collect and store certain confidential information, including personal information of employees and information about partners and clients which may be entitled to protection under a number of regulatory regimes.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In the course of normal and customary business practice, we may share some of this information with vendors who assist us with certain aspects of our business.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Moreover, the success of our operations depends upon the secure transmission of confidential and personal data over public networks, including the use of cashless payments.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Any failure on the part of us or our vendors to maintain the security of data we are required to protect, including via the penetration of our network security and the misappropriation of confidential and personal information, could result in business disruption, damage to our reputation, financial obligations to third parties, fines, penalties, regulatory proceedings and private litigation with potentially large costs, and also result in deterioration in our employees , partners and clients confidence in us and other competitive disadvantages, and thus could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P11_S4	During 2015 and 2014 we did not have any cybersecurity breaches.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We depend on certain key personnel.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Our future success will be largely dependent on the efforts of key management personnel for strategic and operational guidance as well as relationships with our key vendors and customers.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P12_S2	We also believe that our future success will be largely dependent on our continued ability to attract and retain highly qualified management, sales, service, finance and technical personnel.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P12_S3	We cannot assure you that we will be able to attract and retain such personnel.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P12_S4	Further, we make a significant investment in the training of our sales account executives.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P12_S5	Our inability to retain such personnel or to train them either rapidly enough to meet our expanding needs or in an effective manner for quickly changing market conditions could cause a decrease in the overall quality and efficiency of our sales staff, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Risks related to our common stock .
945983_16_ITEM1A_P13_S1	The exercise of outstanding options or any other issuance of shares by us may dilute your ownership of our Common Stock.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Our Common Stock is thinly traded, which may be exacerbated by our repurchases of our Common Stock.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P13_S3	As a result of the thin trading market for our stock, its market price may fluctuate significantly more than the stock market as a whole or of the stock prices of similar companies.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P13_S4	Without a larger float, our common stock will be less liquid than the stock of companies with broader public ownership, and, as a result, the trading prices for our Common Stock may be more volatile.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P13_S5	Among other things, trading of a relatively small volume of our Common Stock may have a greater impact on the trading price of our stock than would be the case if our public float were larger.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our common stock is listed on The NASDAQ Global Market, and we therefore are subject to continued listing requirements, including requirements with respect to the market value and number of publicly-held shares, number of stockholders, minimum bid price, number of market makers and either (i) stockholders equity or (ii) total market value of stock, total assets and total revenues.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P14_S1	If we fail to satisfy one or more of the requirements, we may be delisted from The NASDAQ Global Market.
945983_16_ITEM1A_P14_S2	If we do not qualify for listing on The NASDAQ Capital Market, and if we are not able to list our common stock on another exchange, our common stock could be quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board or on the pink sheets .
945983_16_ITEM1A_P14_S3	As a result, we could face significant adverse consequences including, among others, a limited availability of market quotations for our securities and a decreased ability to issue additional securities or obtain additional financing in the future.

945983_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following management s discussion and analysis of the Company s financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements and the Notes thereto.

945983_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company is organized into two reportable operating segments.
945983_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Lifeboat Distribution segment distributes technical software to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators worldwide.
945983_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.
945983_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage and infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	We market these products through direct sales, the Internet, our catalogs, direct mail programs, advertisements in trade magazines and e-mail promotions.

945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued guidance for revenue recognition for contracts, superseding the previous revenue recognition requirements, along with most existing industry-specific guidance.
945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S1	The guidance requires an entity to review contracts in five steps: 1) identify the contract, 2) identify performance obligations, 3) determine the transaction price, 4) allocate the transaction price, and 5) recognize revenue.
945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S2	The new standard will result in enhanced disclosures regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue arising from contracts with customers.
945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14 which deferred the effective date of the new standard by one year.
945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S4	Along with the deferral of the effective date, ASU No. 2015-14 allows early application as of the original effective date.
945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S5	Entities are allowed to transition to the new standard by either recasting prior periods or recognizing the cumulative effect as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
945983_16_ITEM7_P45_S6	The standard and related amendments will be effective for the Company for its annual reporting period beginning January 1, 2018, including interim periods within that reporting period.
945983_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory (Topic 330) , ( ASU 2015-11 ).
945983_16_ITEM7_P46_S1	Topic 330, Inventory, currently requires an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or market, with market value represented by replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
945983_16_ITEM7_P46_S2	The amendments in ASU 2015-11 require an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
945983_16_ITEM7_P46_S3	ASU 2015-11 is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_16_ITEM7_P46_S4	We do not expect the adoption of this new accounting pronouncement, will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.
945983_16_ITEM7_P47_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2015-17 ( ASU 2015-17 ) to simplify the presentation of deferred taxes.
945983_16_ITEM7_P47_S1	This amendment requires that all deferred tax assets and liabilities, along with any related valuation allowances, be classified as noncurrent on the balance sheet.
945983_16_ITEM7_P47_S2	Adoption of this standard is required for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_16_ITEM7_P47_S3	We do not expect the adoption of ASU 2015-17 will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.

945983_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) of the Exchange Act.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, and effected by the Board of Directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Internal control over financial reporting includes maintaining records in reasonable detail that accurately and fairly reflect our transactions and disposition of assets; providing reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of our financial statements in accordance with GAAP; providing reasonable assurance that receipts and expenditures of the Company, are made in accordance of with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and providing reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Company assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P2_S4	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting is not intended to provide absolute assurance that a misstatement of our financial statements would be prevented or detected.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P2_S5	In addition, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that, owing to changes in conditions, controls may become inadequate, or that the degree of compliance with policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( 2013 Framework).
945983_16_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Based on this evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2015.
945983_16_ITEM9A_P3_S2	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2015 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.

945983_16_ITEM15_P46_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
945983_16_ITEM15_P46_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
945983_16_ITEM15_P47_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
945983_16_ITEM15_P47_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_16_ITEM15_P48_S0	In our opinion, Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in the 2013 Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by COSO.
