945983_16_ITEM15_P54_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries (the Company ), was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.
945983_16_ITEM15_P54_S1	The Company distributes software developed by others through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_16_ITEM15_P54_S2	We also resell computer software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States of America ( USA ) and Canada.
945983_16_ITEM15_P54_S3	We also operate a sales branch in Europe to serve our customers in this region of the world.
945983_16_ITEM15_P54_S4	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_16_ITEM15_P55_S0	The Company is organized into two reportable operating segments.
945983_16_ITEM15_P56_S0	The Lifeboat Distribution segment distributes technical software to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators worldwide.
945983_16_ITEM15_P57_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.
945983_16_ITEM15_P58_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
945983_16_ITEM15_P58_S1	All intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated.
945983_16_ITEM15_P59_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( US GAAP ) requires management to make extensive use of certain estimates and assumptions which affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting periods.
945983_16_ITEM15_P59_S1	The significant areas of estimation include but are not limited to accounting for allowance for doubtful accounts, sales returns, inventory obsolescence, income taxes, depreciation, contingencies and stock-based compensation.
945983_16_ITEM15_P59_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
945983_16_ITEM15_P60_S0	The Company calculates earnings per share in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board FASB ASC Topic 260, Earnings Per Share .
945983_16_ITEM15_P60_S1	Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of Common Stock outstanding during the period.
945983_16_ITEM15_P60_S2	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding, adjusted for potentially dilutive securities including unexercised stock option grants and nonvested shares of restricted stock.
945983_16_ITEM15_P61_S0	A reconciliation of the numerators and denominators of the basic and diluted per share computations follows:
945983_16_ITEM15_P62_S0	The Company considers all liquid short-term investments with original maturities of 90 days or less to be cash equivalents.
945983_16_ITEM15_P63_S0	Accounts receivable principally represents amounts collectible from our customers.
945983_16_ITEM15_P63_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers but generally does not require collateral to support any outstanding obligation.
945983_16_ITEM15_P64_S0	We provide allowances for doubtful accounts related to accounts receivable for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.
945983_16_ITEM15_P64_S1	We take into consideration the overall quality and aging of the receivable portfolio along with specifically identified customer risks.
945983_16_ITEM15_P64_S2	If actual customer payment performance were to deteriorate to an extent not expected, additional allowances may be required.
945983_16_ITEM15_P65_S0	We historically have a low write-off rate, especially on extended payment terms sales transactions.
945983_16_ITEM15_P65_S1	Write-offs on extended payment terms sales transactions as a percentage of net sales amounted to 0.02%, 0.0% and 0.0%, for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
945983_16_ITEM15_P66_S0	Assets and liabilities of the Company s foreign subsidiaries have been translated at the end of the reporting period exchange rates, and related revenues and expenses have been translated at average rates of exchange in effect during the period.
945983_16_ITEM15_P66_S1	Cumulative translation adjustments have been classified within accumulated other comprehensive income, which is a separate component of stockholders equity in accordance FASB ASC Topic No. 220, Comprehensive Income .
945983_16_ITEM15_P67_S0	Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations in credit risk consist of cash and cash equivalents.
945983_16_ITEM15_P68_S0	The Company s cash and cash equivalents, at times, may exceed federally insured limits.
945983_16_ITEM15_P68_S1	The Company s cash and cash equivalents are deposited primarily in banking institutions with global operations.
945983_16_ITEM15_P68_S2	The Company has not experienced any losses in such accounts.
945983_16_ITEM15_P68_S3	The Company believes it is not exposed to any significant credit risk on cash and cash equivalents.
945983_16_ITEM15_P69_S0	The carrying amounts of financial instruments, including cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and accounts payable approximated fair value as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, because of the relative short maturity of these instruments.
945983_16_ITEM15_P69_S1	The Company s accounts receivable long-term is discounted to their present value at prevailing market rates so the balances approximate fair value.
945983_16_ITEM15_P70_S0	Inventory, consisting primarily of finished products held for resale, is stated at the lower of cost (weighted average) or market.
945983_16_ITEM15_P71_S0	Equipment and leasehold improvements are stated at cost.
945983_16_ITEM15_P71_S1	Equipment depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method over three to five years.
945983_16_ITEM15_P72_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized using the straight line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets or the related lease terms, whichever is shorter.
945983_16_ITEM15_P73_S0	Accounts receivable long-term result from product sales with extended payment terms that are discounted to their present values at the prevailing market rates.
945983_16_ITEM15_P73_S1	In subsequent periods, the accounts receivable are increased to the amounts due and payable by the customers through the accretion of interest income on the unpaid accounts receivable due in future years.
945983_16_ITEM15_P73_S2	The amounts under these long-term accounts receivable due within one year are reclassified to the current portion of accounts receivable.
945983_16_ITEM15_P74_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income for the period, the impact of unrealized foreign currency translation adjustments and unrealized gains or losses on available-for-sale marketable securities.
945983_16_ITEM15_P74_S1	The foreign currency translation adjustments are not currently adjusted for income taxes as they relate to permanent investments in international subsidiaries.
945983_16_ITEM15_P75_S0	Revenue on product (software and hardware) and maintenance agreement sales are recognized once four criteria are met: (1) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (2) the price is fixed and determinable, (3) delivery (software and hardware) or fulfillment (maintenance) has occurred, and (4) there is reasonable assurance of collection of the sales proceeds.
945983_16_ITEM15_P75_S1	Revenues from the sales of hardware products, software products and licenses and maintenance agreements are recognized on a gross basis with the selling price to the customer recorded as sales and the acquisition cost of the product recorded as cost of sales.
945983_16_ITEM15_P76_S0	Product delivery to customers occur in a variety of ways, including (i) as physical product shipped from the Company s warehouse, (ii) via drop-shipment by the vendor, or (iii) via electronic delivery for software licenses.
945983_16_ITEM15_P76_S1	The Company leverages drop-ship arrangements with many of its vendors and suppliers to deliver products to customers without having to physically hold the inventory at its warehouse, thereby increasing efficiency and reducing costs.
945983_16_ITEM15_P77_S0	The Company recognizes revenue for drop-ship arrangements on a gross basis.
945983_16_ITEM15_P77_S1	Furthermore, in such drop-ship arrangements, the Company negotiates price with the customer, pays the supplier directly for the product shipped and bears credit risk of collecting payment from its customers.
945983_16_ITEM15_P77_S2	The Company serves as the principal with the customer and, therefore, recognizes the sale and cost of sale of the product upon receiving notification from the supplier that the product has shipped.
945983_16_ITEM15_P78_S0	Maintenance agreements allow customers to obtain technical support directly from the software publisher and to upgrade, at no additional cost, to the latest technology if new applications are introduced by the software publisher during the period that the maintenance agreement is in effect.
945983_16_ITEM15_P79_S0	Sales are recorded net of discounts, rebates, and returns.
945983_16_ITEM15_P79_S1	Vendor rebates and price protection are recorded when earned as a reduction to cost of sales or merchandise inventory, as applicable.
945983_16_ITEM15_P80_S0	Cooperative reimbursements from vendors, which are earned and available, are recorded in the period the related advertising expenditure is incurred.
945983_16_ITEM15_P80_S1	Cooperative reimbursements are recorded as a reduction of cost of sales in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 605-50 Accounting by a Customer (including reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a Vendor.
945983_16_ITEM15_P80_S2	Provisions for returns are estimated based on historical sales returns and credit memo analysis which are adjusted to actual on a periodic basis.
945983_16_ITEM15_P81_S0	The Company has stockholder-approved stock incentive plans for employees and directors.
945983_16_ITEM15_P81_S1	Stock- based compensation is recognized based on the grant date fair value and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is generally the vesting period.
945983_16_ITEM15_P82_S0	The Company utilizes the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
945983_16_ITEM15_P82_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
945983_16_ITEM15_P82_S2	This method also requires a valuation allowance against the net deferred tax asset if, based on the weighted available evidence, it is more likely than not that some or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
945983_16_ITEM15_P83_S0	The Company s policy is to recognize interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions in income tax expense when assessed.
945983_16_ITEM15_P83_S1	The Company accounts for uncertainties in accordance with FASB ASC 740 Income Taxes .
945983_16_ITEM15_P83_S2	This standard clarified the accounting for uncertainties in income taxes.
945983_16_ITEM15_P83_S3	The standard prescribes criteria for recognition and measurement of tax positions.
945983_16_ITEM15_P83_S4	It also provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, and disclosures related to income taxes associated with uncertain tax positions.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued guidance for revenue recognition for contracts, superseding the previous revenue recognition requirements, along with most existing industry-specific guidance.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S1	The guidance requires an entity to review contracts in five steps: 1) identify the contract, 2) identify performance obligations, 3) determine the transaction price, 4) allocate the transaction price, and 5) recognize revenue.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S2	The new standard will result in enhanced disclosures regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue arising from contracts with customers.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14 which deferred the effective date of the new standard by one year.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S4	Along with the deferral of the effective date, ASU No. 2015-14 allows early application as of the original effective date.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S5	Entities are allowed to transition to the new standard by either recasting prior periods or recognizing the cumulative effect as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
945983_16_ITEM15_P84_S6	The standard and related amendments will be effective for the Company for its annual reporting period beginning January 1, 2018, including interim periods within that reporting period.
945983_16_ITEM15_P85_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory (Topic 330) , ( ASU 2015-11 ).
945983_16_ITEM15_P85_S1	Topic 330, Inventory, currently requires an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or market, with market value represented by replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
945983_16_ITEM15_P85_S2	The amendments in ASU 2015-11 require an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
945983_16_ITEM15_P85_S3	ASU 2015-11 is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_16_ITEM15_P85_S4	We do not expect the adoption of this new accounting pronouncement, will have a significant impact on our financial on our financial statements.
945983_16_ITEM15_P86_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2015-17 ( ASU 2015-17 ) to simplify the presentation of deferred taxes.
945983_16_ITEM15_P86_S1	This amendment requires that all deferred tax assets and liabilities, along with any related valuation allowances, be classified as noncurrent on the balance sheet.
945983_16_ITEM15_P86_S2	Adoption of this standard is required for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_16_ITEM15_P86_S3	We do not expect the adoption of ASU 2015-17 will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.

( Citibank ) pursuant to a Business Loan Agreement (the Loan Agreement ), Promissory Note (the Note ), Commercial Security Agreements (the Security Agreements ) and Commercial Pledge Agreement (the Pledge Agreement ).
945983_16_ITEM15_P97_S1	The Credit Facility will be used for business and working capital purposes, including financing of larger extended payment terms sales transactions.
945983_16_ITEM15_P97_S2	On December 18, 2015, the Company signed an extension to this agreement which extended the maturity date to January 31 2019 with all other terms remaining the same.
945983_16_ITEM15_P97_S3	The Credit Facility matures on January 31, 2019, at which time the Company must pay this loan in one payment of any outstanding principal plus all accrued unpaid interest.
945983_16_ITEM15_P97_S4	In addition, the Company will pay regular monthly payments of all accrued unpaid interest.
945983_16_ITEM15_P98_S0	The interest rate for any borrowings under the Credit Facility is subject to change from time to time based on the changes in an independent index which is the LIBOR Rate (the Index ).
945983_16_ITEM15_P98_S1	If the Index becomes unavailable during the term of this loan, Citibank may designate a substitute index after notifying the Company.
945983_16_ITEM15_P98_S2	Interest on the unpaid principal balance of the Note will be calculated using a rate of 1.500 percentage points over the Index.
945983_16_ITEM15_P99_S0	The Credit Facility is secured by the assets of the Company.
945983_16_ITEM15_P100_S0	Among other affirmative covenants set forth in the Loan Agreement, the Company must maintain (i) a ratio of Total Liabilities to Tangible Net Worth (each as defined in the Loan Agreement) of not greater than 2.50 to 1.00, to be tested quarterly and (ii) a minimum Debt Service Coverage Ratio (as defined in the Loan Agreement) of 2.00 to 1.00.
945983_16_ITEM15_P100_S1	Additionally, the Loan Agreement contains negative covenants related to, among other items, prohibitions against the creation of certain liens, engaging in any business activities substantially different than those currently engaged in by the Company, and paying dividends on the Company s stock other than (i) dividends payable in its stock and (ii) cash dividends in amounts and frequency consistent with past practice, without first securing the written consent of Citibank.
945983_16_ITEM15_P100_S2	The Company is in compliance with all covenants at December 31, 2015.

945983_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries (the Company, us, we, or our ) is an information technology ( IT ) channel company.
945983_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	We distribute software and hardware developed by others through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	We also resell computer software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States of America ( USA ) and Canada.
945983_17_ITEM1_P0_S3	In addition we operate a sales branch in Europe to serve our customers in this region of the world.
945983_17_ITEM1_P0_S4	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage and infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.
945983_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our Common Stock is listed on The NASDAQ Global Market under the symbol WSTG .
945983_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our main web site address is www.waysidetechnology.com, and the other web sites maintained by our business include www.lifeboatdistribution.com, and www.techxtend.com.
945983_17_ITEM1_P1_S3	Reference to these uniform resource locators or URLs is made as an inactive textual reference for informational purposes only.
945983_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	Information on our web sites should not be considered filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and is not, and should not be deemed to be, a part of this report.
945983_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Company operates through two reportable operating segments.
945983_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Lifeboat Distribution segment distributes technical software and hardware to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators worldwide.
945983_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.
945983_17_ITEM1_P5_S1	For each of our segments, sales from unaffiliated customers, income and total assets, among other financial information, is presented in Note 9 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
945983_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	The software market is highly competitive.
945983_17_ITEM1_P6_S1	Pricing is very aggressive in both software distribution and reselling.
945983_17_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company expects pricing pressure to continue.
945983_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	The Company faces competition from a wide variety of sources.
945983_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	In the Lifeboat Distribution segment, we compete against much larger broad-line distributors, as well as specialty distributors and, in some cases, the direct sales teams of the vendors we represent also sell directly to the end-customers.
945983_17_ITEM1_P7_S2	In the TechXtend segment, we also compete against vendors who sell directly to customers, as well as software resellers, superstores, e-commerce vendors, and other direct marketers of software and hardware products.
945983_17_ITEM1_P7_S3	In both segments, some of our competitors are significantly larger and have substantially greater resources than the Company.
945983_17_ITEM1_P7_S4	Many of our competitors compete principally on the basis of price, product availability, customer service and technical support.
945983_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	There can be no assurance that the Company can compete effectively against existing competitors or new competitors that may enter the market or that it can generate profit margins which represent a fair return to the Company.
945983_17_ITEM1_P8_S1	In addition, price is an important competitive factor in the personal computer software market and there can be no assurance that the Company will not be subject to increased price competition.
945983_17_ITEM1_P8_S2	An increase in the amount of competition faced by the Company, or its failure to compete effectively against its competitors, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations.
945983_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	The Company competes to attract prospective buyers and in sourcing new products from software developers and publishers, as well as in marketing its current product line to its customers.
945983_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	The Company competes to gain distribution rights for new products primarily on the basis of its reputation for successfully bringing new products to market and its relationships with software publishers.
945983_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	The market for the software products we sell is characterized by rapid changes in technology, user requirements, and customer specifications.
945983_17_ITEM1_P11_S1	The manner in which software products are distributed and sold is changing, and new methods of distribution and sale may emerge or expand.
945983_17_ITEM1_P11_S2	Software developers and publishers have sold, and may intensify their efforts to sell, their products directly to end-users.
945983_17_ITEM1_P11_S3	The continuing evolution of the Internet as a platform in which to conduct e-commerce business transactions has both lowered the barriers for competition and broadened customer access to products and information, increasing competition and reducing prices.
945983_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	From time to time, certain software developers and publishers have instituted programs for the direct sale of large order quantities of software to certain major corporate accounts.
945983_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	These types of programs may continue to be developed and used by various developers and publishers.
945983_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	While some software developers and publishers currently sell new releases or upgrades directly to end users, they have not attempted to completely bypass the distribution and reseller channels.
945983_17_ITEM1_P13_S1	There can be no assurances, however, that software developers and publishers will continue using distributors and resellers to the same extent they currently do.
945983_17_ITEM1_P13_S2	Future efforts by software developers and publishers to bypass third- party sales channels could materially and adversely affect the Company s business operations and financial conditions.
945983_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	In addition, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services.
945983_17_ITEM1_P14_S1	Any of these competitive programs, if successful, could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.

945983_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should carefully consider the risk factors set forth below as well as the other information contained in this report.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or those currently viewed by us to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Changes in the information technology industry and/or economic environment may reduce demand for the products and services we sell.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our results of operations are influenced by a variety of factors, including the condition of the IT industry, general economic conditions, shifts in demand for, or availability of, computer products and software and IT services and industry introductions of new products, upgrades or methods of distribution.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The information technology products industry is characterized by abrupt changes in technology, rapid changes in customer preferences, short product life cycles and evolving industry standards.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Net sales can be dependent on demand for specific product categories, and any change in demand for or supply of such products could have a material adverse effect on our net sales, and/or cause us to record write-downs of obsolete inventory, if we fail to react in a timely manner to such changes.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We rely on our suppliers for product availability, marketing funds, purchasing incentives and competitive products to sell.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We acquire products for resale both directly from manufacturers and indirectly from distributors.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The loss of a supplier could cause a disruption in the availability of products.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Additionally, there is no assurance that as manufacturers continue to or increasingly sell directly to end users and through the distribution channel, that they will not limit or curtail the availability of their products to distributors/resellers like us.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S4	For example, resellers and publishers may attempt to increase the volume of software products distributed electronically through ESD (Electronic Software Distribution) technology, through subscription services, and through on-line shopping services, and correspondingly, decrease the volume of products sold through us.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Our inability to obtain a sufficient quantity of products, or an allocation of products from a manufacturer in a way that favors one of our competitors, or competing distribution channels, relative to us, could cause us to be unable to fill clients orders in a timely manner, or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S6	We also rely on our suppliers to provide funds for us to market their products, including through our on-line marketing efforts, and to provide purchasing incentives to us.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P3_S7	If any of the suppliers that have historically provided these benefits to us decides to reduce such benefits, our expenses would increase, adversely affecting our results of operations.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	General economic weakness may reduce our revenues and profits.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Generally, economic downturns, may cause some of our current and potential customers to delay or reduce technology purchases, resulting in longer sales cycles, slower adoption of new technologies and increased price competition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We may, therefore, experience a greater decline in demand for the products we sell, resulting in increased competition and pressure to reduce the cost of operations.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Any benefits from cost reductions may take longer to realize and may not fully mitigate the impact of the reduced demand.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P4_S4	In addition, weak financial and credit markets heighten the risk of customer bankruptcies and create a corresponding delay in collecting receivables from those customers and may also affect our vendors ability to supply products, which could disrupt our operations.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P4_S5	The realization of any or all of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We depend on having creditworthy customers to avoid an adverse impact to our operating results and financial condition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P5_S1	We require sufficient amounts of debt and equity capital to fund our transactions as we provide larger extended payment terms to certain of our customers.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If the credit quality of our customer base materially decreases, or if we experience a material increase in our credit losses, we may find it difficult to continue to obtain the required capital for our business, and our operating results and financial condition may be harmed.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition to the impact on our ability to attract capital, a material increase in our delinquency and default experience would itself have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	whom we provide larger extended payment terms go elsewhere for financing, such loss of financing revenue could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The IT products and services industry is intensely competitive and actions of competitors, including manufacturers of products we sell, can negatively affect our business.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Competition has been based primarily on price, product availability, speed of delivery, credit availability and quality and breadth of product lines and, increasingly, also is based on the ability to tailor specific solutions to client needs.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P7_S2	We compete with manufacturers, including manufacturers of products we sell, as well as a large number and wide variety of marketers and resellers of IT products and services.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P7_S3	In addition, manufacturers are increasing the volume of software products they distribute electronically directly to end-users and in the future will likely pay lower referral fees for sales of certain software licensing agreements sold by us.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Generally, pricing is very aggressive in the industry, and we expect pricing pressures to continue.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P8_S1	There can be no assurance that we will be able to negotiate prices as favorable as those negotiated by our competitors or that we will be able to offset the effects of price reductions with an increase in the number of clients, higher net sales, cost reductions, or greater sales of services, which service sales typically at higher gross margins, or otherwise.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Price reductions by our competitors that we either cannot or choose not to match could result in an erosion of our market share and/or reduced sales or, to the extent we match such reductions, could result in reduced operating margins, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We operate in a very competitive business environment.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Like other companies in the technology distribution industry, the Company s business is continually under pricing pressure and characterized by narrow gross and operating margins.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P9_S2	These narrow margins magnify the impact on the Company s operating results attributed to variations in sales and operating costs and place a premium on our ability to leverage our infrastructure.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Future gross and operating margins may be adversely affected by changes in product mix, vendor pricing actions and competitive and economic pressures.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P10_S1	In addition, failure to attract new sources of business from expansion of products or services or entry into new markets may adversely affect future gross and operating margins.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P11_S0	If we lose several of our larger customers our earnings may be affected.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Meeting our customers needs quickly and fairly is critical to our business success.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Our contracts for the provision of products are generally non-exclusive agreements that are terminable by either party upon 30 days notice.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P11_S3	In addition, our agreements with these larger customers do not provide for minimum purchase commitments.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P11_S4	The loss of several of our large customers, the failure of such customers to pay their accounts receivable on a timely basis, or a material reduction in the amount of purchases made by such customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P11_S5	Additionally, anything that negatively impacts our customer relations also can negatively impact our operating results.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Disruptions in our information technology and voice and data networks could affect our ability to service our clients and cause us to incur additional expenses.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We believe that our success to date has been, and future results of operations likely will be, dependent in large part upon our ability to provide prompt and efficient service to clients.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Our ability to provide such services is dependent largely on the accuracy, quality and utilization of the information generated by our IT systems, which affect our ability to manage our sales, client service, distribution, inventories and accounting systems and the reliability of our voice and data networks.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Failure to adequately maintain the security of our electronic and other confidential information could materially adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We are dependent upon automated information technology processes.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Privacy, security, and compliance concerns have continued to increase as technology has evolved to facilitate commerce and as cross-border commerce increases.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	As part of our normal business activities, we collect and store certain confidential information, including personal information of employees and information about partners and clients which may be entitled to protection under a number of regulatory regimes.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In the course of normal and customary business practice, we may share some of this information with vendors who assist us with certain aspects of our business.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Moreover, the success of our operations depends upon the secure transmission of confidential and personal data over public networks, including the use of cashless payments.

945983_17_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Risks related to our common stock .
945983_17_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The exercise of options or any other issuance of shares by us may dilute your ownership of our Common Stock.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Our Common Stock is thinly traded, which may be exacerbated by our repurchases of our Common Stock.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P18_S3	As a result of the thin trading market for our stock, its market price may fluctuate significantly more than the stock market as a whole or of the stock prices of similar companies.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P18_S4	Without a larger float, our common stock will be less liquid than the stock of companies with broader public ownership, and, as a result, the trading prices for our Common Stock may be more volatile.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Among other things, trading of a relatively small volume of our Common Stock may have a greater impact on the trading price of our stock than would be the case if our public float were larger.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our common stock is listed on The NASDAQ Global Market, and we therefore are subject to continued listing requirements, including requirements with respect to the market value and number of publicly-held shares, number of stockholders, minimum bid price, number of market makers and either (i) stockholders equity or (ii) total market value of stock, total assets and total revenues.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P19_S1	If we fail to satisfy one or more of the requirements, we may be delisted from The NASDAQ Global Market.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P19_S2	If we do not qualify for listing on The NASDAQ Capital Market, and if we are not able to list our common stock on another exchange, our common stock could be quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board or on the pink sheets .
945983_17_ITEM1A_P19_S3	As a result, we could face significant adverse consequences including, among others, a limited availability of market quotations for our securities and a decreased ability to issue additional securities or obtain additional financing in the future.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P20_S0	If the company fails to maintain an effective system of internal controls or discovers material weaknesses in its internal controls over financial reporting, it may not be able to report its financial results accurately or timely or detect fraud, which could have a material adverse effect on its business.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P21_S0	An effective internal control environment is necessary for the company to produce reliable financial reports and is an important part of its effort to prevent financial fraud.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P21_S1	The company is required to annually evaluate the effectiveness of the design and operation of its internal controls over financial reporting.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P21_S2	Based on these evaluations, the company may conclude that enhancements, modifications, or changes to internal controls are necessary or desirable.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P22_S0	While management evaluates the effectiveness of the company's internal controls on a regular basis, these controls may not always be effective.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P22_S1	There are inherent limitations on the effectiveness of internal controls, including collusion, management override, and failure in human judgment.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P22_S2	In addition, control procedures are designed to reduce rather than eliminate financial statement risk.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P22_S3	If the company fails to maintain an effective system of internal controls, or if management or the company's independent registered public accounting firm discovers material weaknesses in the company's internal controls, it may be unable to produce reliable financial reports or prevent fraud, which could have a material adverse effect on the company's business.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P22_S4	In addition, the company may be subject to sanctions or investigation by regulatory authorities, such as the SEC or the NASDAQ.
945983_17_ITEM1A_P22_S5	Any such actions could result in an adverse reaction in the financial markets due to a loss of confidence in the reliability of the company's financial statements, which could cause the market price of its common stock to decline or limit the company's access to capital.

945983_17_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following management s discussion and analysis of the Company s financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements and the Notes thereto.

945983_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	We distribute software and hardware developed by others through resellers indirectly to customers worldwide.
945983_17_ITEM7_P1_S1	We also resell computer software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the USA and Canada.
945983_17_ITEM7_P1_S2	In addition, we operate a sales branch in Europe to serve our customers in this region of the world.
945983_17_ITEM7_P1_S3	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage and infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_17_ITEM7_P1_S4	We market these products through creative marketing communications, including our web sites, local and on-line seminars, webinars, social media, direct e-mail, and printed materials.
945983_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company is organized into two reportable operating segments.
945983_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Lifeboat Distribution segment distributes technical software to corporate resellers, value added resellers (VARs), consultants and systems integrators worldwide.
945983_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.
945983_17_ITEM7_P5_S0	We derive the majority of our net sales though the sale of third party software licenses, maintenance and service agreements.
945983_17_ITEM7_P5_S1	In our Lifeboat distribution segment, sales are impacted by the number of product lines we distribute, and sales penetration of those products into the reseller channel.
945983_17_ITEM7_P5_S2	sales are generally driven by sales force effectiveness and success in providing superior customer service, competitive pricing, and flexible payment solutions to our customers.
945983_17_ITEM7_P5_S3	Our sales are also impacted by external factors such as levels of IT spending and customer demand for products we distribute.
945983_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	We sell in a competitive environment where gross product margins have historically declined due to competition and changes in product mix towards products where no delivery of a physical product is required.
945983_17_ITEM7_P6_S1	To date, we have been able to implement cost efficiencies such as the use of drop shipments, electronic ordering ( EDI ) and other capabilities to be able to operate our business profitably as gross margins have declined.
945983_17_ITEM7_P7_S0	Selling general and administrative expenses are comprised mainly of employee salaries, commissions and other employee related expenses, facility costs, costs to maintain our IT infrastructure, public company compliance costs and professional fees.
945983_17_ITEM7_P7_S1	We monitor our level of accounts payable, inventory turnover and accounts receivable turnover which are measures of how efficiently we utilize capital in our business.
945983_17_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company s sales, gross profit and results of operations have fluctuated and are expected to continue to fluctuate on a quarterly basis as a result of a number of factors, including but not limited to: the condition of the software industry in general, shifts in demand for software products, pricing, level of extended payment terms sales transactions, industry shipments of new software products or upgrades, fluctuations in merchandise returns, adverse weather conditions that affect response, distribution or shipping, shifts in the timing of holidays and changes in the Company s product offerings.
945983_17_ITEM7_P9_S0	The Company s operating expenditures are based on sales forecasts.
945983_17_ITEM7_P9_S1	If sales do not meet expectations in any given quarter, operating results may be materially adversely affected.

945983_17_ITEM7_P15_S0	Management s discussion and analysis of the Company s financial condition and results of operations are based upon the Company s consolidated financial statements that have been prepared in accordance with US GAAP.
945983_17_ITEM7_P15_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
945983_17_ITEM7_P16_S0	Revenues from the sales of hardware products, software products, licenses, maintenance and subscription agreements are recognized on a gross basis upon delivery or fulfillment, with the selling price to the customer recorded as sales and the acquisition cost of the product recorded as cost of sales.
945983_17_ITEM7_P17_S0	On an on-going basis, the Company evaluates its estimates, including those related to product returns, bad debts, inventories, investments, intangible assets, income taxes, stock-based compensation, contingencies and litigation.
945983_17_ITEM7_P18_S0	The Company bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
945983_17_ITEM7_P18_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
945983_17_ITEM7_P19_S0	The Company believes the following critical accounting policies used in the preparation of its consolidated financial statements affect its more significant judgments and estimates.
945983_17_ITEM7_P20_S0	The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of its customers to make required payments.
945983_17_ITEM7_P20_S1	Management determines the estimate of the allowance for uncollectible accounts receivable by considering a number of factors, including: historical experience, aging of the accounts receivable, and specific information obtained by the Company on the financial condition and the current creditworthiness of its customers.
945983_17_ITEM7_P21_S0	If the financial condition of the Company s customers were to deteriorate, resulting in an impairment of their ability to make payments, additional allowances may be required.
945983_17_ITEM7_P22_S0	If actual sales returns are greater than estimated by management, additional expense may be incurred.
945983_17_ITEM7_P23_S0	The Company s accounts receivable long-term are discounted to their present value at prevailing market rates at the time of sale based on prevailing rates.
945983_17_ITEM7_P23_S1	In doing so, the Company considers competitive market rates and other factors.
945983_17_ITEM7_P24_S0	The Company writes down its inventory for estimated obsolescence or unmarketable inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
945983_17_ITEM7_P24_S1	If actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, additional inventory write-offs may be required.
945983_17_ITEM7_P25_S0	The Company has considered future taxable income and ongoing prudent and feasible tax planning strategies in assessing the need for the valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets.
945983_17_ITEM7_P25_S1	In the event the Company were to determine that it would not be able to realize all or part of its net deferred tax assets in the future, an adjustment to the deferred tax assets would be charged to income in the period such determination was made.
945983_17_ITEM7_P26_S0	Under the fair value recognition provision, stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is the vesting period.
945983_17_ITEM7_P27_S0	We make certain assumptions in order to value and expense our various share-based payment awards.
945983_17_ITEM7_P27_S1	In connection with valuing stock options, we use the Black-Scholes model, which requires us to estimate certain subjective assumptions.
945983_17_ITEM7_P27_S2	The key assumptions we make are: the expected volatility of our stock; the expected term of the award; and the expected forfeiture rate.
945983_17_ITEM7_P28_S0	In connection with our restricted stock programs we make assumptions principally related to the forfeiture rate.
945983_17_ITEM7_P28_S1	We review our valuation assumptions periodically and, as a result, we may change our valuation assumptions used to value stock based awards granted in future periods.
945983_17_ITEM7_P28_S2	Such changes may lead to a significant change in the expense we recognize in connection with share-based payments.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued guidance for revenue recognition for contracts, superseding the previous revenue recognition requirements, along with most existing industry-specific guidance.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S1	The guidance requires an entity to review contracts in five steps: 1) identify the contract, 2) identify performance obligations, 3) determine the transaction price, 4) allocate the transaction price, and 5) recognize revenue.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S2	The new standard will result in enhanced disclosures regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue arising from contracts with customers.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ASU 2015-14 ( ASU 2015-14 ) which deferred the effective date of the new standard by one year.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S4	Along with the deferral of the effective date, ASU No. 2015-14 allows early application as of the original effective date.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S5	Entities are allowed to transition to the new standard by either recasting prior periods or recognizing the cumulative effect as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S6	The standard and related amendments will be effective for the Company for its annual reporting period beginning January 1, 2018, including interim periods within that reporting period.
945983_17_ITEM7_P29_S7	The Company is in the process of developing its conclusions on several aspects of the standard including principal versus agent considerations, identification of performance obligations, the determination of when control of goods and services transfers to the Company s customer, which transition approach will be applied and the estimated impact it will have on our consolidated financial statements.
945983_17_ITEM7_P30_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015-11, "Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory (Topic 330)", ("ASU 2015-11").
945983_17_ITEM7_P30_S1	Topic 330, Inventory, currently requires an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or market, with market value represented by replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
945983_17_ITEM7_P30_S2	The amendments in ASU 2015-11 require an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
945983_17_ITEM7_P30_S3	ASU 2015-11 is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_17_ITEM7_P30_S4	We do not expect the adoption of this new accounting pronouncement, will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.
945983_17_ITEM7_P31_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ("ASU") 2016-09, Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting ("ASU 2016-09").
945983_17_ITEM7_P31_S1	ASU 2016-09 simplifies several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment transactions, including the income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities and classification on the statement of cash flows.
945983_17_ITEM7_P31_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_17_ITEM7_P31_S3	We do not expect the adoption of this new accounting pronouncement to have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.
945983_17_ITEM7_P32_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, Leases ("ASU 2016-02").
945983_17_ITEM7_P32_S1	Topic 840, Leases, resulting in the creation of FASB ASC Topic 842, Leases.
945983_17_ITEM7_P33_S0	ASU 2016-02 requires a lessee to recognize in the statement of financial position a liability to make lease payments and a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset for the lease term for both finance and operating leases.
945983_17_ITEM7_P33_S1	This ASU is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2018.
945983_17_ITEM7_P33_S2	The Company is currently assessing the potential impact of adopting ASU 2016-02 on its consolidated financial statements.

945983_17_ITEM7_P34_S1	ASU No. 2016-13 revises the methodology for measuring credit losses on financial instruments and the timing of when such losses are recorded.

945983_17_ITEM7_P35_S1	The new standard will become effective for the Company beginning with the first quarter of 2018, with early adoption permitted.
945983_17_ITEM7_P35_S2	The adoption of this guidance will not have a material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
945983_17_ITEM7_P36_S0	In October 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-16, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Intra-Entity Transfers of Assets Other Than Inventory.
945983_17_ITEM7_P36_S1	This amendment is intended to improve accounting for the income tax consequences of intra-entity transfers of assets other than inventory.
945983_17_ITEM7_P36_S2	In accordance with this guidance, an entity should recognize the income tax consequences of an intra-entity transfer of an asset other than inventory when the transfer occurs.
945983_17_ITEM7_P36_S3	The ASU is effective for the Company beginning in fiscal 2019.
945983_17_ITEM7_P36_S4	Early adoption is permitted in fiscal 2018 with modified retrospective application.
945983_17_ITEM7_P36_S5	The Company is continuing to evaluate the impact of the adoption of this guidance on its consolidated financial statements.

945983_17_ITEM7_P37_S1	The year-to-year comparison of financial results is not necessarily indicative of future results:
945983_17_ITEM7_P38_S0	Net sales for the year ended December 31, 2016 increased 9%, or $36.0 million, to $418.1 million, compared to $382.1 million for the same period in 2015.
945983_17_ITEM7_P38_S1	Net sales increased in both our Lifeboat Distribution segment and our TechXtend segment.
945983_17_ITEM7_P39_S0	Lifeboat Distribution segment net sales for the year ended December 31, 2016 increased $29.8 million, or 9% to $369.5 million, compared to $339.7 million for the same period a year earlier.
945983_17_ITEM7_P39_S1	The increase was primarily due to increased penetration of existing products into new and existing distribution partner accounts, as well as the addition of several new product lines.
945983_17_ITEM7_P39_S2	The increases were partially offset by turnover in some vendor and distribution accounts due to competitive bid situations.
945983_17_ITEM7_P40_S0	We operate in a competitive market in which some sales agreements are subject to periodic competitive bidding processes, resulting in fluctuations from year to year based on the outcome.
945983_17_ITEM7_P41_S0	TechXtend segment net sales increased $6.2 million or 15% to $48.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, compared to $42.4 million for the prior year.
945983_17_ITEM7_P41_S1	The increase was primarily due to higher sales to major accounts on extended payment terms, partially offset by the impact of a reduced number of sales people and lower revenues from marketing services.
945983_17_ITEM7_P42_S0	We extend payment terms on some enterprise account sales, typically for periods of one to three years, to provide flexibility for our customers.
945983_17_ITEM7_P42_S1	We reduced our number of sales people late in 2015 to streamline and focus our operations on opportunities with the highest financial return.
945983_17_ITEM7_P43_S0	Gross Profit for the year ended December 31, 2016 increased 3% or $0.8 million, to $27.3 million, compared to $26.6 million for the same period in 2015.
945983_17_ITEM7_P43_S1	Lifeboat Distribution segment gross profit increased 4% to $22.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to $21.5 million for the same period in the prior year.
945983_17_ITEM7_P43_S2	TechXtend segment gross profit remained flat at $5.0 million for each of 2016 and 2015.
945983_17_ITEM7_P43_S3	Gross profit amounts reflect increased sales volumes and competitive pressures on gross profit margins discussed below.
945983_17_ITEM7_P44_S0	Gross profit margin (gross profit as a percentage of net sales) for the year ended December 31, 2016 was 6.5% compared to 7.0% in 2015.
945983_17_ITEM7_P44_S1	Lifeboat Distribution segment gross profit margin was 6.0% for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to 6.3% in 2015.
945983_17_ITEM7_P44_S2	The decrease in gross profit margin for the Lifeboat Distribution segment was primarily caused by competitive pricing pressure and product mix.
945983_17_ITEM7_P45_S0	trend has been for gross profit margins to decline for the past several years.
945983_17_ITEM7_P45_S1	We attribute some of the decline to an increasing portion of our revenues coming from the sale of licenses, maintenance and service agreements that are not associated with a physical product.
945983_17_ITEM7_P45_S2	While our gross profit margin has declined on these products, we have been able to maintain our profitability through efficiencies gained in electronic ordering and distribution through the use of EDI and other automation.
945983_17_ITEM7_P45_S3	TechXtend segment gross profit margin for the year ended December 31, 2016 was 10.2% compared to 11.9% in 2015.
945983_17_ITEM7_P45_S4	The decrease in gross profit margin was due to competitive market pricing, particularly on larger enterprise sales.
945983_17_ITEM7_P45_S5	Sales of large enterprise licenses typically carry a lower gross profit margin, and lower incremental selling and administrative costs as a percentage of revenue, than smaller account sales.
945983_17_ITEM7_P46_S0	Vendor rebates and discounts for each of the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 was $2.0 million.
945983_17_ITEM7_P47_S0	Vendor rebates are dependent on reaching certain targets set by our vendors.
945983_17_ITEM7_P47_S1	The Company monitors vendor rebate levels, competitive pricing, and gross profit margins carefully.
945983_17_ITEM7_P47_S2	We anticipate that price competition in our market will continue in both of our business segments.

945983_17_ITEM7_P48_S1	The increase is primarily due to increased stock based compensation and employee related expenses to support our growth, costs related to the relocation to our new offices in October, 2016, and professional expenses related to public company compliance.

945983_17_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P0_S1	As required by Rule 13a-15(b) under the Exchange Act, our management carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures , as such term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act, as of the end of the period covered by this report.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P0_S2	This evaluation was carried out under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our Company s President, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer (principal executive officer), Vice President and Chief Financial Officer (principal financial officer) , and Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer (principal accounting officer).
945983_17_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Based upon that evaluation, the Company s Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Accounting Officer concluded that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective, as of the end of the period covered by this report, to ensure that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms and is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management, including the Company s Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Accounting Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) of the Exchange Act.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, our Chief Executive Officer , Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Accounting Officer, and effected by the Board of Directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Internal control over financial reporting includes maintaining records in reasonable detail that accurately and fairly reflect our transactions and disposition of assets; providing reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of our financial statements in accordance with GAAP; providing reasonable assurance that receipts and expenditures of the Company, are made in accordance of with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and providing reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Company assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P1_S4	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting is not intended to provide absolute assurance that a misstatement of our financial statements would be prevented or detected.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P1_S5	In addition, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that, owing to changes in conditions, controls may become inadequate, or that the degree of compliance with policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer , Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( 2013 Framework).
945983_17_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Based on this evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2016.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P2_S2	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2016 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Our independent registered public accounting firm, EisnerAmper LLP, has audited our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016.
945983_17_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Their attestation report on the audit of our internal control over financial reporting is included below.

945983_17_ITEM15_P29_S0	An entity s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
945983_17_ITEM15_P29_S1	An entity s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the entity; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the entity are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the entity; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the entity s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
945983_17_ITEM15_P30_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
945983_17_ITEM15_P30_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
945983_17_ITEM15_P31_S0	In our opinion, Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016, based on criteria established in the 2013 Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by COSO.

945983_17_ITEM15_P37_S0	Wayside Technology Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries (the Company ), was incorporated in Delaware in 1982.

945983_17_ITEM15_P37_S2	We also resell computer software and hardware developed by others and provide technical services directly to customers in the United States of America ( USA ) and Canada.

945983_17_ITEM15_P37_S4	We offer an extensive line of products from leading publishers of software and tools for virtualization/cloud computing, security, networking, storage infrastructure management, application lifecycle management and other technically sophisticated domains as well as computer hardware.
945983_17_ITEM15_P38_S0	The Company is organized into two reportable operating segments.

945983_17_ITEM15_P40_S0	The TechXtend segment is a value-added reseller of software, hardware and services for corporations, government organizations and academic institutions in the USA and Canada.

945983_17_ITEM15_P43_S2	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding, adjusted for potentially dilutive securities including unexercised stock option grants and nonvested shares of restricted stock.

945983_17_ITEM15_P56_S0	Accounts receivable-long-term result from product sales with extended payment terms that are discounted to their present values at the prevailing market rates at the time of sale.
945983_17_ITEM15_P56_S1	In subsequent periods, the accounts receivable are increased to the amounts due and payable by the customers through the accretion of interest income on the unpaid accounts receivable due in future years.
945983_17_ITEM15_P56_S2	The amounts under these long-term accounts receivable due within one year are reclassified to the current portion of accounts receivable.
945983_17_ITEM15_P57_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income for the period, the impact of unrealized foreign currency translation adjustments The foreign currency translation adjustments are not currently adjusted for income taxes as they relate to permanent investments in international subsidiaries.
945983_17_ITEM15_P58_S0	Revenue on product (software and hardware) and maintenance and subscription agreement sales are recognized once four criteria are met: (1) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (2) the price is fixed and determinable, (3) delivery (software and hardware) or fulfillment (maintenance and subscription) has occurred, and (4) there is reasonable assurance of collection of the sales proceeds.
945983_17_ITEM15_P58_S1	Revenues from the sales of hardware products, software products and licenses, maintenance and subscription agreements are recognized on a gross basis upon delivery or fulfillment with the selling price to the customer recorded as sales and the acquisition cost of the product recorded as cost of sales.
945983_17_ITEM15_P59_S0	Product delivery to customers occur in a variety of ways, including (i) as physical product shipped from the Company s warehouse, (ii) via drop-shipment by the vendor, or (iii) via electronic delivery for software licenses.
945983_17_ITEM15_P59_S1	The Company leverages drop-ship arrangements with many of its vendors and suppliers to deliver products to customers without having to physically hold the inventory at its warehouse, thereby increasing efficiency and reducing costs.
945983_17_ITEM15_P60_S0	The Company recognizes revenue for drop-ship arrangements on a gross basis.
945983_17_ITEM15_P60_S1	Furthermore, in such drop-ship arrangements, the Company negotiates price with the customer, pays the supplier directly for the product shipped and bears credit risk of collecting payment from its customers.
945983_17_ITEM15_P61_S0	maintenance and subscription agreement is in effect.
945983_17_ITEM15_P62_S0	The Company serves as the principal with the customer and, therefore, recognizes the sale and cost of sale of the product upon receiving notification from the supplier that the product has shipped or the contract has been fulfilled.
945983_17_ITEM15_P63_S0	Sales are recorded net of discounts, rebates, and returns.
945983_17_ITEM15_P63_S1	Vendor rebates and price protection are recorded when earned as a reduction to cost of sales or merchandise inventory, as applicable.
945983_17_ITEM15_P64_S0	Cooperative reimbursements from vendors, which are earned and available, are recorded in the period the related advertising expenditure is incurred.
945983_17_ITEM15_P64_S1	Cooperative reimbursements are recorded as a reduction of cost of sales in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 605-50 Accounting by a Customer (including reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a Vendor.
945983_17_ITEM15_P64_S2	Provisions for returns are estimated based on historical sales returns and credit memo analysis which are adjusted to actual on a periodic basis.
945983_17_ITEM15_P65_S0	The Company has stockholder-approved stock incentive plans for employees and directors.
945983_17_ITEM15_P65_S1	Stock- based compensation is recognized based on the grant date fair value and is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, which is generally the vesting period.
945983_17_ITEM15_P66_S0	The Company utilizes the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
945983_17_ITEM15_P66_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
945983_17_ITEM15_P66_S2	This method also requires a valuation allowance against the net deferred tax asset if, based on the weighted available evidence, it is more likely than not that some or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
945983_17_ITEM15_P67_S0	The Company s policy is to recognize interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions in income tax expense when assessed.
945983_17_ITEM15_P67_S1	The Company accounts for uncertainties in accordance with FASB ASC 740 Income Taxes .
945983_17_ITEM15_P67_S2	This standard clarified the accounting for uncertainties in income taxes.
945983_17_ITEM15_P67_S3	The standard prescribes criteria for recognition and measurement of tax positions.
945983_17_ITEM15_P67_S4	It also provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, and disclosures related to income taxes associated with uncertain tax positions.
945983_17_ITEM15_P67_S5	The Company classifies all deferred tax asset or liabilities as non-current on the balance sheet in accordance with ASU 2015-17 which the Company has adopted.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued guidance for revenue recognition for contracts, superseding the previous revenue recognition requirements, along with most existing industry-specific guidance.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S1	The guidance requires an entity to review contracts in five steps: 1) identify the contract, 2) identify performance obligations, 3) determine the transaction price, 4) allocate the transaction price, and 5) recognize revenue.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S2	The new standard will result in enhanced disclosures regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue arising from contracts with customers.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ASU 2015-14 ( ASU 2015-14 ) which deferred the effective date of the new standard by one year.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S4	Along with the deferral of the effective date, ASU No. 2015-14 allows early application as of the original effective date.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S5	Entities are allowed to transition to the new standard by either recasting prior periods or recognizing the cumulative effect as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S6	The standard and related amendments will be effective for the Company for its annual reporting period beginning January 1, 2018, including interim periods within that reporting period.
945983_17_ITEM15_P68_S7	The Company is in the process of developing its conclusions on several aspects of the standard including principal versus agent considerations, identification of performance obligations, the determination of when control of goods and services transfers to the Company s customers, which transition approach will be applied and the estimated impact it will have on our consolidated financial statements.
945983_17_ITEM15_P69_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015-11, "Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory (Topic 330)", ("ASU 2015-11").
945983_17_ITEM15_P69_S1	Topic 330, Inventory, currently requires an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or market, with market value represented by replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
945983_17_ITEM15_P69_S2	The amendments in ASU 2015-11 require an entity to measure inventory at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
945983_17_ITEM15_P69_S3	ASU 2015-11 is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
945983_17_ITEM15_P69_S4	We do not expect the adoption of this new accounting pronouncement, will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.

( Citibank ) pursuant to a Business Loan Agreement (the Loan Agreement ), Promissory Note (the Note ), Commercial Security Agreements (the Security Agreements ) and Commercial Pledge Agreement (the Pledge Agreement ).
945983_17_ITEM15_P87_S1	The Credit Facility will be used for business and working capital purposes, including financing of larger extended payment terms sales transactions.

945983_17_ITEM15_P88_S1	If the Index becomes unavailable during the term of this loan, Citibank may designate a substitute index after notifying the Company.
945983_17_ITEM15_P88_S2	Interest on the unpaid principal balance of the Note will be calculated using a rate of 1.500 percentage points over the Index.
945983_17_ITEM15_P89_S0	The Credit Facility is secured by the assets of the Company.
945983_17_ITEM15_P90_S0	Among other affirmative covenants set forth in the Loan Agreement, the Company must maintain (i) a ratio of Total Liabilities to Tangible Net Worth (each as defined in the Loan Agreement) of not greater than 2.50 to 1.00, to be tested quarterly and (ii) a minimum Debt Service Coverage Ratio (as defined in the Loan Agreement) of 2.00 to 1.00.
945983_17_ITEM15_P90_S1	Additionally, the Loan Agreement contains negative covenants related to, among other items, prohibitions against the creation of certain liens, engaging in any business activities substantially different than those currently engaged in by the Company, and paying dividends on the Company s stock other than (i) dividends payable in its stock and (ii) cash dividends in amounts and frequency consistent with past practice, without first securing the written consent of Citibank.
945983_17_ITEM15_P90_S2	The Company is in compliance with all covenants at December 31, 2016.
